 Context and general aim 
 The tremendous progress of neuroimaging
 genomic and biomarker technologies has allowed capturing various characteristics of brain diseases in living patients. 
 Collection of multimodal data in large patient databases provides a comprehensive view of brain alterations
 biological processes
 genetic risk factors and symptoms. The team aims to build numerical models of brain diseases from multimodal patient based on 
 appropriate data-driven approaches. To this end
 we develop new data representations and statistical learning approaches that can integrate multiple types of data: neuroimaging
 peripheral biomarkers
 clinical and omics data (genetics
 transcriptomics). In particular
 we develop methods to highlight networks of interactions among multiple sources of data
 to track data changes during disease progression
 and to automatically predict current or future clinical outcomes from these data. We apply these models to neurodegenerative diseases 
 (Alzheimer\'s disease and other dementias
 multiple sclerosis
 Parkinson\'s disease...). They shall allow deepening our understanding of neurological diseases and developing new decision support systems
 for diagnosis
 prognosis and design of clinical trials.  
 
 New representations from multimodal medical images <div class="col-md-8 classictext">Combining multiple neuroimaging modalities is necessary 
 to obtain a comprehensive picture of alterations in brain diseases (atrophy
 anatomical disconnections
 functional connectivity alterations
 metabolic alterations
 abnormal protein deposits…). Such a combination is a non-trivial task because different types of information are conveyed by the different 
 modalities
 which in turns leads to different natural data representations (meshes and curves for geometrical information
 signals
 networks). We propose to build new integrated data representations from multiple modalities. Such representations will be subsequently 
 entered into statistical models and decision support systems. Specifically
 we will introduce representations that can integrate geometrical information (anatomical surfaces extracted from anatomical MRI
 white matter tracts extracted from diffusion MRI) together with functional (PET
 ASL
 EEG/MEG) and microstructural information. 
 <img src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/img_topics_3.png" alt="" width="100%" />  
 
 Network theoretic approaches to integrate heterogeneous brain networks 
 <img src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/img_network_2.png" alt="" width="100%" /> 
 <div class="classictext col-md-8">
 The complexity of biological systems often emerges from interactions between components at multiple spatial and temporal scales.
  Neglecting this information
 and analyzing separately the levels of such scales
 is an oversimplification of the real phenomenon. We propose a methodological framework that aims
 on the one hand
 to integrate information from networks describing different modes of connectivity (e.g. multi-modal
 cross-frequency) and
 on the other hand
 to statistically model the organizational mechanisms of temporally dynamic networks (e.g. nonstationary
 longitudinal). Target applications include: i) human learning in brain-computer interface
 ii) prediction of neurodegenerative disease progression
 and iii) identification of driving nodes in biological pathways (gene expression networks).  Spatio-temporal models to build trajectories of 
 disease progression from longitudinal data <div class="classictext col-md-8">  Longitudinal data sets are collected to capture variable 
 temporal phenomena
 which may be due to ageing or disease progression for instance. They consist in the observation of several individuals
 each of them being observed at multiple points in time. The statistical exploitation of such data sets is notably difficult since data of 
 each individual follow a different trajectory of changes and at its own pace. Our team has contributed to the definition of a generic theoretical and 
 algorithmic framework for learning typical trajectories from longitudinal data sets. This framework is built on tools from Riemannian geometry and 
 the inference is based on a stochastic Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm coupled with Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods.   
 <img src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/img_long_topics.png" alt="" width="100%" />  
 
 Decision support systems for diagnosis
 prognosis and design of clinical trials 
 <img class="wp-image-1500 alignright" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Capture-d’écran-2018-11-22-à-18.26.12.png" alt="" width="100%" />
  <div class="classictext col-md-8">Based on the new representations and statistical models
 we design decision support systems for diagnosis
 prognosis and design of clinical trials. These systems are based on: i) personalization of statistical models to predict evolution at the 
 patient level; ii) new machine learning approches for classification and regression on high-dimensional and structured data; iii) content-based
  retrieval techniques.

 'If you are interested in joining the team
 do not hesitate to send us an e-mail stating your field of interest and a CV. We may have other open positions than those advertised below. You can directly contact one of the "https://www.aramislab.fr/?page_id=4"  faculty members</a> of the team
 or the "mailto:olivier.colliot@cnrs.fr">head</a> of the team for a general inquiry. Our team is pluridisciplinary and we welcome applicants with different profiles and varied expertise (computer science
 electrical engineering
 neuroimaging
 neuroscience
 medicine...).  '2014-02-12 18:54:47'

 ' Head<blockquote> <ul> 	Olivier Colliot - CNRS Researcher (CR1
 HDR)  </blockquote>  Deputy Head<blockquote> <ul> 	Didier Dormont - Professor of Neuroradiology (PU-PH)
 University Pierre and Marie Curie / AP-HP  </blockquote>  Researchers<blockquote> <ul> 	Mario Chavez - CNRS Researcher (CR1) 	Marie Chupin - CNRS Research Engineer (IR) 	Stanley Durrleman - INRIA Researcher  </blockquote>  Medical Faculty / Clinicians<blockquote> <ul> 	Claude Adam  - Neurologist (PH)
 AP-HP 	Anne Bertrand - Neuroradiologist (CCA)
 AP-HP 	Sophie Dupont - Professor of Neurology (PU-PH),  University Pierre and Marie Curie / AP-HP 	Damien Galanaud - Professor of Neuroradiology (PU-PH),  University Pierre and Marie Curie / AP-HP 	Dominique Hasboun - Associate Professor of Neuroanatomy (MCU), University Pierre and Marie Curie 	Yves Samson - Professor of Neuroradiology (PU-PH),  University Pierre and Marie Curie / AP-HP 	Lionel Thivard - Neurologist (PH)

 'If you are interested in joining the team
 do not hesitate to send us an e-mail stating your field of interest and a CV. We may have other open positions than those advertised below. You can directly contact one of the "https://www.aramislab.fr/?page_id=4"  faculty members</a> of the team
 or the "mailto:olivier.colliot@cnrs.fr">head</a> of the team for a general inquiry. Our team is pluridisciplinary and we welcome applicants with different profiles and varied expertise (computer science
 electrical engineering
 neuroimaging
 neuroscience
 medicine...).\n Postdocs / Scientists</h2>\n<ul>\n 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/postdoc_EN-v1.pdf">Deep Learning for Brain Imaging</a> - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: from 1 to 3 years - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date:  anytime - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contact: olivier.colliot@cnrs.fr\n\n PhD thesis</h2>\n<div class="page" title="Page 1">\n<div class="layoutArea">\n<div class="column">\n<ul>\n 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/these-benchmarking-validation.pdf">Deep learning for assisting clinical decisions in brain imaging: trustworthy validation and benchmarking</a> - Starting date: autumn 2024 (flexible)\n 	<s>"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/PhD_EDS-v1.pdf"  rel="noopener">Artificial intelligence tools for clinical data warehouses in neuroimaging</a> - Starting date:  autumn 2024 - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: ninon.burgos@cnrs.fr
 olivier.colliot@cnrs.fr
 sophie.loizillon@icm-institute.org</s>\n\n\n\n\n Engineers / Software developers</h2>\n<ul>\n 	<s>"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/2023_Clinica.pdf"  rel="noopener">Research Engineer</a> - Brain image analysis - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date:  March 2024 - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contact: ninon.burgos@cnrs.fr</s>\n\n<div class="page" title="Page 1">\n<div class="layoutArea">\n<div class="column">\n<ul>\n 	<s>"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/clinicaDL_job_offer_v1.0.pdf">Research Engineer</a> - Deep learning for brain image analysis - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date:  as soon as possible - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contact: camille.brianceau@icm- institute.org</s>\n\n\n\n\n  Master 2 Internships /  Stages de Master 2\n</em></h2>\n<ul>\n 	\n<div class="page" title="Page 1">\n<div class="layoutArea">\n<div class="column">\n\n&nbsp;\n\n\n\n\n'

 (110
 1
 '2014-03-03 16:27:43'
 '2014-03-03 15:27:43'
 ' <strong><span style="color: #000000;">Head</strong><ul> 	<span style="color: #1772af;"> Olivier Colliot</em> - CNRS Researcher (CR1
 HDR) - "http://cogimage.dsi.cnrs.fr/perso/colliot/" >webpage</a> -   <strong>Deputy Head</strong><ul> 	<span style="color: #1772af;"> Didier Dormont </em><span style="font-family: arial
 sans-serif;">- Professor of Neuroradiology (PU-PH)

 ' <span style="color: #000000;">Head<ul> 	Olivier Colliot<span style="font-family: arial

 '<strong>If you are interested in joining the team (with respect to any of our research topics)
 do not hesitate to send us an e-mail stating your field of interest and a CV. We may have other open positions than those advertised below. </strong>You can directly contact one of the "https://www.aramislab.fr/?page_id=4" >permanent researchers</a> of the team
 or the "mailto:olivier.colliot@upmc.fr">head</a> of the team for a general inquiry. Our team is pluridisciplinary and we welcome applicants with different profiles and expertises (computer science
 electrical engineering
 neuroimaging
 neuroscience
 medicine...).\n<h1><span style="font-size: 20px;">Postdocs / Scientists\n</h1>\n<ul>\n	"https://www.aramislab.fr/files/job_offers/JobOffer_ARAMIS.pdf">Statistical Learning in Medical Imaging</a> - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: from 2 to 5 years - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: January 2016 - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contact: stanley.durrleman@inria.fr\n	"https://www.aramislab.fr/files/job_offers/joboffer_anne.pdf" >Histological MR Imaging of proteinopathies at 11.7T</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 24 months  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contact: anne.bertrand@psl.aphp.fr\n"https://www.aramislab.fr/files/job_offers/joboffer_anne.pdf" >Histological MR Imaging of proteinopathies at 11.7T</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 24 months  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contact: anne.bertrand@psl.aphp.fr\n\n – Duration: from 2 to 3 years – Starting date: 1 April2016 – Contact: fabrizio [dot] devicofallani [at] gmail [dot] com\n\n\n\n<h1><span style="font-size: 20px;">PhD thesis\n</h1>\n<ul>\n	"https://www.aramislab.fr/files/job_offers/PhD_Inria_ICM.pdf">Learning methods for the spatiotemporal analysis of longitudinal data - Applications to the diagnosis
 prognosis and monitoring of Alzheimer’s disease</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: September 2016 (maybe combined with an internship in Spring 2016) - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contact: stanley.durrleman@inria.fr\n\n Software developers</h2>\n<ul>\n	"https://www.aramislab.fr/files/job_offers/SoftwareEngineer_Inria_ICM.pdf">Development of a software product for the construction of virtual models of brain disease progression </a>- <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: from 2 to 4 years - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: January 2016 - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contact: stanley.durrleman@inria.fr\n\n  Master Internships /  Stages de Master</em></h2>\n<ul>\n	"https://www.aramislab.fr/files/job_offers/sujet_stage_Primates.pdf" >Comparaison de l’anatomie et de la fonction du cerveau de l’Homme avec d’autres espèces de primates</a> - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contact: stanley.durrleman@inria.fr\n	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/stage_segmentation_hippoHR_finale20160119.pdf" >Segmentation automatisée des sous régions de l\'hippocampe humain en IRM in-vivo à très haut champ</a> - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 6 months - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contact: marie.chupin@upmc.fr\n'

 '<ul> 	 <h3>Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</h3>  	 <h3>Modeling dynamical brain networks from EEG/MEG</h3>  	 <h3>Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</h3>  '
 'Research topics'
 ''
 'inherit'
 'open'
 'open'

 (256
 1
 '2014-03-14 09:59:34'
 '2014-03-14 08:59:34'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong></h2>\n<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p>\n<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p>\n<p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p>\n&nbsp;\n\n<strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong>\n<p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p>\n<p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>\n\n<ul>\n	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions\n	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations\n	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time\n	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>\n\nFunctional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).\n\nWithin this area
 our main research topics are:\n<ul>\n	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns\n	causality analysis\n	analysis of time-varying networks\n	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>\n\nLarge-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited. Our team aims at developing new statistical approaches to discover relevant patterns from such datasets and to integrate multimodal data from imaging and genomics. We also have a strong practical expertise in managing and analyzing massive multicenter datasets.\n\nWithin this area
 our main research topics are:\n<ul>\n	machine learning approaches to extract biomarkers\n	multimodal analysis approaches for bridging imaging and genomics\n	methodologies for multicenter neuroimaging datasets (see CATI project below)\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong>\n<p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p>\n<p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 our team is particularly involved in:</p>\n\n<ul>\n	standardization of MRI acquisitions\n	quality control of MRI scans\n	processing of anatomical MRI data\n	development of new tools for image analysis (segmentation
 morphometry)\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations\n <strong>External collaborations</strong></h2>\n Methodological collaborations \n<ul>\n	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>)\n	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>)\n	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia)\n	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >University of London</a>
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>)\n	Inria "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>)\n	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> ("http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique7" >Jean-François Mangin</a>

 (270
 1

 (329
 1
 '2018-12-05 16:28:09'
 '2018-12-05 15:28:09'
 '    Context and general aim</h2>\n\nThe tremendous progress of neuroimaging
 genomic and biomarker technologies has allowed to capture various characteristics of brain diseases in living patients. Collection of multimodal data in large patient databases provides a comprehensive view of brain alterations
 biological processes
 genetic risk factors and symptoms. The team aims to build numerical models of brain diseases from multimodal patient based on appropriate data-driven approaches. To this end
 we develop new data representations and statistical learning approaches that can integrate multiple types of data: neuroimaging
 peripheral biomarkers
 clinical and omics data (genetics
 transcriptomics).\nIn particular
 we develop methods to highlight networks of interactions among multiple sources of data
 to track data changes during disease progression
 and to automatically predict current or future clinical outcomes from these data. We apply these models to neurodegenerative diseases (Alzheimer\'s disease and other dementias
 Multiple Sclerosis
 Parkinson\'s disease...). They shall allow to deepen our understanding of neurological diseases and to develop new decision support systems for diagnosis
 prognosis and design of clinical trials.\n\n[su_divider style="default" divider_color="#702082" top="no" link_color="#702082" size="1" margin="16"]\nNew representations from multimodal medical images</h2>\n\n<div class="col-md-8 classictext">Combining multiple neuroimaging modalities is necessary to obtain a comprehensive picture of alterations in brain diseases (atrophy
 anatomical disconnections
 functional connectivity alterations
 metabolic alterations
 abnormal protein deposits…). Such a combination is a non-trivial task because different types of information are conveyed by the different modalities
 which in turns leads to different natural data representations (meshes and curves for geometrical information
 signals
 networks). We propose to build new integrated data representations from multiple modalities. Such representations will be subsequently entered into statistical models and decision support systems. Specifically
 we will introduce representations that can integrate geometrical information (anatomical surfaces extracted from anatomical MRI
 white matter tracts extracted from diffusion MRI) together with functional (PET
 ASL
 EEG/MEG) and microstructural information.\n\n\n[su_divider style="default" divider_color="#702082" top="no" link_color="#702082" size="1" margin="16"]\nNetwork theoretic approaches to integrate heterogeneous brain networks</h2>\n\n<img src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/networkv3.png" alt="" width="100%" />\n<div class="classictext col-md-8">The complexity of biological systems often emerges from interactions between components at multiple spatial and temporal scales. Neglecting this information
 and analyzing separately the levels of such scales
 is an oversimplification of the real phenomenon. We propose a methodological framework that aims
 on the one hand
 to integrate information from networks describing different modes of connectivity (e.g. multi-modal
 cross-frequency) and
 on the other hand
 to statistically model the organizational mechanisms of temporally dynamic networks (e.g. nonstationary
 longitudinal). Target applications include: i) human learning in brain-computer interface
 ii) prediction of neurodegenerative disease progression
 and iii) identification of driving nodes in biological pathways (gene expression networks).\n\n[su_divider style="default" divider_color="#702082" top="no" link_color="#702082" size="1" margin="16"]\nSpatio-temporal models to build trajectories of disease progression from longitudinal data</h2>\n\n<div class="classictext col-md-8">\n\nLongitudinal data sets are collected to capture variable temporal phenomena
 which may be due to ageing or disease progression for instance. They consist in the observation of several individuals
 each of them being observed at multiple points in time. The statistical exploitation of such data sets is notably difficult since data of each individual follow a different trajectory of changes and at its own pace. Our team has contributed to the definition of a generic theoretical and algorithmic framework for learning typical trajectories from longitudinal data sets. This framework is built on tools from Riemannian geometry and the inference is based on a stochastic Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm coupled with Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods.\n\n\n<img src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/longitudinal.png" alt="" width="100%" />\n\n[su_divider style="default" divider_color="#702082" top="no" link_color="#702082" size="1" margin="16"]\nDecision support systems for diagnosis
 prognosis and design of clinical trials</h2>\n\n<img class="wp-image-1500 alignright" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Capture-d’écran-2018-11-22-à-18.26.12.png" alt="" width="100%" />\n<div class="classictext col-md-8">Based on the new representations and statistical models
 we design decision support systems for diagnosis
 prognosis and design of clinical trials. These systems are based on: i) personalization of statistical models to predict evolution at the patient level; ii) new machine learning approches for classification and regression on high-dimensional and structured data; iii) content-based retrieval techniques.\n\n[su_divider style="default" divider_color="#702082" top="no" link_color="#702082" size="1" margin="16"]\nExternal collaborations</h2>\n Methodological collaborations \n \n 	King\'s College London
 UK ("http://cmic.cs.ucl.ac.uk/staff/sebastien_ourselin/"  rel="noopener">Sébastien Ourselin</a>)\n 	"http://www.ucl.ac.uk/cmic/homepage"  rel="noopener">Center for Medical Image Computing</a>
 University College London
 UK ("http://www0.cs.ucl.ac.uk/staff/D.Alexander/"  rel="noopener">Daniel Alexander</a>)\n 	"https://www.erasmusmc.nl/?lang=en">Erasmus Medical Center (EMC)</a>
 Rotterdam
 Netherlands ("http://bigr.nl/people/StefanKlein/">Stefan Klein</a>
 "https://www.erasmusmc.nl/schildkliercentrum/centrum/medewerkers/vernooij/">Meike W. Vernooij</a>
 "http://bigr.nl/people/WiroNiessen/">Wiro Niessen</a>)\n 	Tandon School of Engineering
 New York University
 USA ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/~gerig/"  rel="noopener">Guido Gerig</a>)\n 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/"  rel="noopener">Queen Mary</a> "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/"  rel="noopener">University of London</a>
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/"  rel="noopener">Vito Latora</a>)\n 	"https://www.cmrr.umn.edu/"  rel="noopener">Center for Magnetic Resonance Research</a>
 University of Minnesota
 USA\n("http://www.cmrr.umn.edu/facultystaff/pfvdm.shtml"  rel="noopener">Pierre-François Van de Moortele</a>
 Tom Henry
 "http://www.neurosci.umn.edu/faculty/ugurbil.html"  rel="noopener">Kamil Ugurbil</a>)\n 	Inria"https://team.inria.fr/epione/"> Epione</a>
 Sophia-Antipolis
 France ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html"  rel="noopener">Nicholas Ayache</a>)\n 	Center for Applied Mathematics
 "http://ens-paris-saclay.fr/"  rel="noopener">ENS Paris-Saclay</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/"  rel="noopener">Alain Trouvé</a>)\n 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/"  rel="noopener">Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/"  rel="noopener">Joan Glaunès</a>)\n 	"http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/index.php?clear=1"  rel="noopener">Laboratoire AMIS</a>
 Université Paul Sabatier

 ' Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRIHERE TEXT <p style="padding-left: 30px;">------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>  <ul> 	  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 18px;">Modeling dynamical brain networks from EEG/MEG  <p style="padding-left: 60px;">here text</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>  <ul> 	<span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial

 (387
 1
 '2014-03-09 18:36:26'
 '2014-03-09 17:36:26'
 ' Context and general aimUnderstanding brain function and its alterations requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets (e.g. Alzheimer’s disease neuroimaging initiative [ADNI]
 gene expression atlases from the Allen Institute...). In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.  The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings). The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...  These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies (mainly neurodegenerative diseases
 epilepsy and cerebrovascular disorders) in close collaboration with neuroradiologists and neurologists
 in order to: <i>i)</i> provide insight into their physiopathology; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.;  Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRIHERE TEXT <p style="padding-left: 30px;">------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>  <ul> 	  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 18px;">Modeling dynamical brain networks from EEG/MEG  <p style="padding-left: 60px;">here text</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>  <ul> 	<span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 18px;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)  <p style="padding-left: 60px;">Here text</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>  <ul> 	<span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 18px;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies  <p style="padding-left: 60px;">Here text</p>  <h1>Collaborations</h1>  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research

 '2014-03-09 18:37:19'

 ' Context and general aimUnderstanding brain function and its alterations requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets (e.g. Alzheimer’s disease neuroimaging initiative [ADNI]
 gene expression atlases from the Allen Institute...). In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.  The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings). The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...  These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies (mainly neurodegenerative diseases
 epilepsy and cerebrovascular disorders) in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.;  Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRIHERE TEXT <p style="padding-left: 30px;">------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>  <ul> 	  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'

 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 18px;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)  <p style="padding-left: 60px;">Here text</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>  <ul> 	<span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial

 (389
 1
 '2014-03-09 19:02:03'
 '2014-03-09 18:02:03'
 ' Context and general aimUnderstanding brain function and its alterations requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets (e.g. Alzheimer’s disease neuroimaging initiative [ADNI]
 gene expression atlases from the Allen Institute...). In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.  The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings). The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...  These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies (mainly neurodegenerative diseases
 epilepsy and cerebrovascular disorders) in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.;  Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRIHERE TEXT <p style="padding-left: 30px;">-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p> <p style="padding-left: 60px;"></p> <p style="padding-left: 60px;"></p> <p style="padding-left: 60px;">here text</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p> Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data) <p style="padding-left: 60px;">Here text</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p>   CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studiesOur team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies at the best level. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in AD
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects at the earliest stage of the disease).  Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control
 development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Dedicated engineers have been recruited to further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 22px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. Queen Mary University of London

 (390
 1
 '2014-03-09 19:12:01'
 '2014-03-09 18:12:01'
 ' Context and general aim<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings). The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies (mainly neurodegenerative diseases
 epilepsy and cerebrovascular disorders) in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI <p style="padding-left: 30px;">---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;"></p>   Modeling dynamical brain networksFunctional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow to characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data);  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in AD
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects at the earliest stage of the disease).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Dedicated engineers have been recruited to further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 22px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. Queen Mary University of London
 UK (V. Latora) 	INRIA Asclepios (Nicholas Ayache) 	CEA Neurospin (Jean-François Mangin
 Cyril Poupon
 Vincent Frouin
 Lucie Hertz-Pannier
 Jean-Baptiste Poline) 	Center for Magnetic Resonance Research
 University of Minnesota
 USA (Pierre-François Van de Moortele
 Tom Henry
 Kamil Ugurbil) 	Scientific Computing and Imaging (SCI) Institute
 University of Utah
 USA (Guido Gerig
 Sarang Joshi
 Marcel Prastawa) 	INRIA Visages (Christian Barillot) 	Laboratoire AMIS
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse (José Braga
 Jean Dumoncel) 	Institut Pasteur
 Paris (Roberto Toro) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 ENS Ulm
 Paris (B. Cazelles)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit
 University of Oxford
 UK (J. Mena-Segovia) 	Massachusetts General Hospital
 Harvard University
 USA (R. Gupta) 	Department of Neurology
 Lariboisière Hospital

 (392
 1
 '2014-03-09 19:28:00'
 '2014-03-09 18:28:00'
 ' Context and general aim<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies (such as Alzheimer\'s disease
 
 epilepsy and cerebrovascular disorders) in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI <p style="padding-left: 30px;"></p> <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data);  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 22px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. Queen Mary University of London

 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France.  to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <h1>Collaborations</h1>  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research

 '2014-03-09 19:30:59'
 '2014-03-09 18:30:59'
 ' Context and general aim<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context

 epilepsy and cerebrovascular disorders) in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data);  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp; <h1>Collaborations</h1>  External collaborations<h5>Methodological collaborations</h5> <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research

 (395
 1
 '2014-03-09 19:32:44'
 '2014-03-09 18:32:44'
 ' Context and general aim<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data);  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp; <h1>Collaborations</h1>  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. Queen Mary University of London

 Jean-Baptiste Poline) 	Center for Magnetic Resonance Research

 ' Context and general aim<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI; <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"></p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining brain imaging
 “omics”
 electrophysiology
 cognitive tests
 clinical data
 are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp; <h1>Collaborations</h1>  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. Queen Mary University of London

 0),
 (403
 1
 '2014-03-09 20:15:30'
 '2014-03-09 19:15:30'
 ' Context and general aim<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining brain imaging
 “omics”
 electrophysiology
 cognitive tests
 clinical data
 are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp; <h1>Collaborations</h1>  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune

 Andreas Hartmann
 Yulia Worbe) 	ICM Richard Miles\'s team 	ICM Stéphane Charpier\'s team 	Department of Neuroradiology
 Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital '
