 0),
 (404
 1
 '2014-03-09 20:23:47'
 '2014-03-09 19:23:47'
 ' Context and general aim<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications  <span style="color: red; text-decoration: line-through;">  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp; <h1>Collaborations</h1>  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. Queen Mary University of London
 UK (V. Latora) 	INRIA Asclepios (Nicholas Ayache) 	CEA Neurospin (Jean-François Mangin
 Cyril Poupon
 Vincent Frouin
 Lucie Hertz-Pannier
 Jean-Baptiste Poline) 	Center for Magnetic Resonance Research
 University of Minnesota
 USA (Pierre-François Van de Moortele
 Tom Henry
 Kamil Ugurbil) 	Scientific Computing and Imaging (SCI) Institute
 University of Utah
 USA (Guido Gerig
 Sarang Joshi
 Marcel Prastawa) 	INRIA Visages (Christian Barillot) 	Laboratoire AMIS
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse (José Braga
 Jean Dumoncel) 	Institut Pasteur
 Paris (Roberto Toro) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 ENS Ulm
 Paris (B. Cazelles)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit
 University of Oxford
 UK (J. Mena-Segovia) 	Massachusetts General Hospital
 Harvard University
 USA (R. Gupta) 	Department of Neurology
 Lariboisière Hospital
 Paris (Hugues Chabriat) 	Sainte-Anne Hospital
 Paris (Catherine Oppenheim
 Marie Sarazin) 	Kremlin-Bicêtre Hospital
 Paris (Emmanuelle Corruble
 Florence Gressier
 Romain Colle) 	Bordeaux University Hospital (Carole Dufouil) 	Cycéron
 Caen University Hospital (Gaël Chételat
 Francis Eustache
 Béatrice Desgranges) 	Lille University Hospital (Christine Delmaire)   Local collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	CENIR MRI core facility (Stéphane Lehéricy
 Eric Bardinet
 Romain Valabrègue) 	CENIR MEG/EEG core facility (Nathalie George
 Denis Schwartz
 Laurent Hugueville) 	CENIR Stereotaxy core facility (Sara Fernandez-Vidal) 	ICM/IHU Bioinformatics/biostatistics core facility (Ivan Moszer) 	Laboratoire d\'Imagerie Biomédicale (Habib Benali)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	IM2A / ICM Bruno Dubois\'s team (Bruno Dubois
 Harald Hampel
 Stéphane Epelbaum) 	ICM Alexis Brice\'s team (Alexis Brice
 Isabelle Le Ber
 Christel Depienne) 	ICM Marie Vidailhet / Stéphane Lehéricy\'s team (Marie Vidailhet
 Stéphane Lehéricy
 Andreas Hartmann
 Yulia Worbe) 	ICM Richard Miles\'s team 	ICM Stéphane Charpier\'s team 	Department of Neuroradiology
 Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital '

 '2014-03-09 20:26:44'
 '2014-03-09 19:26:44'
 ' Context and general aim<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp; <h1>Collaborations</h1>  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research

 do not hesitate to send us an e-mail stating your field of interest and a CV. We may have other open positions than those advertised below. </strong>You can directly contact one of the permanent researchers of the team
 or the head of the team for a general inquiry. Our team is pluridisciplinary and we welcome applicants with different profiles and expertises (computer science
 electrical engineering
 neuroimaging
 neuroscience
 medicine...). <h1><span style="font-size: 20px;">Postdocs</h1> <ul> 	"http://www.inria.fr/en/institute/recruitment/offers/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/campaign-2014/(view)/details.html?id=PNGFK026203F3VBQB6G68LOE1&amp;ContractType=4546&amp;LG=EN&amp;Resultsperpage=20&amp;nPostingID=8265&amp;nPostingTargetID=13985&amp;option=52&amp;sort=DESC&amp;nDepartmentID=19" >Shape analysis of brain structures using 7T MRI</a>   -   <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 12 to 24 months  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: around november 2014 (possibility to start earlier)   Master Internships / Stages de Master<ul> 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/stage_7T.pdf" >Anatomie Computationnelle de la Structure interne de l\'Hippocampe à partir d\'IRM 7 Tesla à très haute Résolution Spatiale</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/stage_classification.pdf" >Automatic Classification of Patients with Alzheimer\'s Disease from Magnetic Resonance Imaging data</a>   - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible   Other positions&nbsp;'

 '2014-03-10 10:08:41'
 '2014-03-10 09:08:41'
 '<strong>If you are interested in joining the team (with respect to any of our research topics)
 do not hesitate to send us an e-mail stating your field of interest and a CV. We may have other open positions than those advertised below. </strong>You can directly contact one of the "https://www.aramislab.fr/?page_id=4" >permanent researchers</a> of the team
 or the head of the team for a general inquiry. Our team is pluridisciplinary and we welcome applicants with different profiles and expertises (computer science
 electrical engineering
 neuroimaging
 neuroscience
 medicine...). <h1><span style="font-size: 20px;">Postdocs</h1> <ul> 	"http://www.inria.fr/en/institute/recruitment/offers/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/campaign-2014/(view)/details.html?id=PNGFK026203F3VBQB6G68LOE1&amp;ContractType=4546&amp;LG=EN&amp;Resultsperpage=20&amp;nPostingID=8265&amp;nPostingTargetID=13985&amp;option=52&amp;sort=DESC&amp;nDepartmentID=19" >Shape analysis of brain structures using 7T MRI</a>   -   <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 12 to 24 months  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: around november 2014 (possibility to start earlier)   Master Internships /  Stages de Master</em><ul> 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/stage_7T.pdf" >Anatomie computationnelle de la structure interne de l\'hippocampe à partir d\'IRM 7 Tesla à très haute résolution spatiale</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/stage_classification.pdf" >Automatic classification of patients with Alzheimer\'s disease from Magnetic Resonance Imaging data</a>   - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible   &nbsp;'

 '2014-03-10 10:09:19'
 '2014-03-10 09:09:19'
 '<strong>If you are interested in joining the team (with respect to any of our research topics)
 do not hesitate to send us an e-mail stating your field of interest and a CV. We may have other open positions than those advertised below. </strong>You can directly contact one of the "https://www.aramislab.fr/?page_id=4" >permanent researchers</a> of the team
 or the "mailto: olivier.colliot@upmc.fr" >head</a> of the team for a general inquiry. Our team is pluridisciplinary and we welcome applicants with different profiles and expertises (computer science
 electrical engineering
 neuroimaging
 neuroscience
 medicine...). <h1><span style="font-size: 20px;">Postdocs</h1> <ul> 	"http://www.inria.fr/en/institute/recruitment/offers/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/campaign-2014/(view)/details.html?id=PNGFK026203F3VBQB6G68LOE1&amp;ContractType=4546&amp;LG=EN&amp;Resultsperpage=20&amp;nPostingID=8265&amp;nPostingTargetID=13985&amp;option=52&amp;sort=DESC&amp;nDepartmentID=19" >Shape analysis of brain structures using 7T MRI</a>   -   <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 12 to 24 months  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: around november 2014 (possibility to start earlier)   Master Internships /  Stages de Master</em><ul> 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/stage_7T.pdf" >Anatomie computationnelle de la structure interne de l\'hippocampe à partir d\'IRM 7 Tesla à très haute résolution spatiale</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/stage_classification.pdf" >Automatic classification of patients with Alzheimer\'s disease from Magnetic Resonance Imaging data</a>   - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible   &nbsp;'

 ' <img class=" wp-image-61 aligncenter" alt="Picture_Aramis" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Picture_Aramis-1024x578.jpg" width="819" height="462" /> <span style="color: #000000;">Direction<ul> 	Olivier Colliot - CNRS Researcher (CR1

 (419
 1
 '2014-03-10 11:24:21'
 '2014-03-10 10:24:21'
 ' Context and general aim<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp; <span style="color: #008c9e;font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 22px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  External collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. Queen Mary University of London
 UK (V. Latora) 	INRIA Asclepios (Nicholas Ayache) 	CEA Neurospin (Jean-François Mangin
 Cyril Poupon
 Vincent Frouin
 Lucie Hertz-Pannier
 Jean-Baptiste Poline) 	Center for Magnetic Resonance Research
 University of Minnesota
 USA (Pierre-François Van de Moortele
 Tom Henry
 Kamil Ugurbil) 	Scientific Computing and Imaging (SCI) Institute
 University of Utah
 USA (Guido Gerig
 Sarang Joshi
 Marcel Prastawa) 	INRIA Visages (Christian Barillot) 	Laboratoire AMIS
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse (José Braga
 Jean Dumoncel) 	Institut Pasteur
 Paris (Roberto Toro) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 ENS Ulm
 Paris (B. Cazelles)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit
 University of Oxford
 UK (J. Mena-Segovia) 	Massachusetts General Hospital
 Harvard University
 USA (R. Gupta) 	Department of Neurology
 Lariboisière Hospital
 Paris (Hugues Chabriat) 	Sainte-Anne Hospital
 Paris (Catherine Oppenheim
 Marie Sarazin) 	Kremlin-Bicêtre Hospital
 Paris (Emmanuelle Corruble
 Florence Gressier
 Romain Colle) 	Bordeaux University Hospital (Carole Dufouil) 	Cycéron
 Caen University Hospital (Gaël Chételat
 Francis Eustache
 Béatrice Desgranges) 	Lille University Hospital (Christine Delmaire)   Local collaborations Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	CENIR MRI core facility (Stéphane Lehéricy
 Eric Bardinet
 Romain Valabrègue) 	CENIR MEG/EEG core facility (Nathalie George
 Denis Schwartz
 Laurent Hugueville) 	CENIR Stereotaxy core facility (Sara Fernandez-Vidal) 	ICM/IHU Bioinformatics/biostatistics core facility (Ivan Moszer) 	Laboratoire d\'Imagerie Biomédicale (Habib Benali)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	IM2A / ICM Bruno Dubois\'s team (Bruno Dubois
 Harald Hampel
 Stéphane Epelbaum) 	ICM Alexis Brice\'s team (Alexis Brice
 Isabelle Le Ber
 Christel Depienne) 	ICM Marie Vidailhet / Stéphane Lehéricy\'s team (Marie Vidailhet
 Stéphane Lehéricy
 Andreas Hartmann
 Yulia Worbe) 	ICM Richard Miles\'s team 	ICM Stéphane Charpier\'s team 	Department of Neuroradiology
 Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital '

 ' Context and general aim<p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized

 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized

 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial

 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI

 (421
 1
 '2014-03-10 11:26:00'
 '2014-03-10 10:26:00'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software. We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong>  Methodological collaborations</em>  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. Queen Mary University of London
 UK (V. Latora) 	INRIA Asclepios (Nicholas Ayache) 	CEA Neurospin (Jean-François Mangin
 Cyril Poupon
 Vincent Frouin
 Lucie Hertz-Pannier
 Jean-Baptiste Poline) 	Center for Magnetic Resonance Research

 USA (Pierre-François Van de Moortele

 USA (Guido Gerig
 Sarang Joshi
 Marcel Prastawa) 	INRIA Visages (Christian Barillot) 	Laboratoire AMIS
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse (José Braga
 Jean Dumoncel) 	Institut Pasteur
 Paris (Roberto Toro) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 ENS Ulm
 Paris (B. Cazelles)    Medical collaborations</em>  <ul> 	Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit

 UK (J. Mena-Segovia) 	Massachusetts General Hospital

 Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital '

 and Colliot O. The ADNI

 ' <img class=" wp-image-61 aligncenter" alt="Picture_Aramis" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Picture_Aramis-1024x578.jpg" width="819" height="462" /> <span style="color: #000000;">Direction<ul> 	Olivier Colliot - CNRS Researcher (CR1

 0),
 (430
 1
 '2014-03-11 09:10:09'
 '2014-03-11 08:10:09'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.  TO BE COMPLETED;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software (segmentation
 morphometry
 machine learning). We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong>  Methodological collaborations</em>  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research

 (437
 1
 '2014-03-11 16:35:43'
 '2014-03-11 15:35:43'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.  TO BE COMPLETED;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software (segmentation
 morphometry
 machine learning). We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	ENS de Cachan (Alain Trouvé) 	Université Paris-Descartes (Joan Glaunès) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. Queen Mary University of London
 UK (V. Latora) 	INRIA Asclepios (Nicholas Ayache) 	CEA Neurospin (Jean-François Mangin
 Cyril Poupon
 Vincent Frouin
 Lucie Hertz-Pannier
 Jean-Baptiste Poline) 	Center for Magnetic Resonance Research
 University of Minnesota
 USA (Pierre-François Van de Moortele
 Tom Henry
 Kamil Ugurbil) 	Scientific Computing and Imaging (SCI) Institute
 University of Utah
 USA (Guido Gerig
 Sarang Joshi
 Marcel Prastawa) 	INRIA Visages (Christian Barillot) 	Laboratoire AMIS
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse (José Braga
 Jean Dumoncel) 	Institut Pasteur
 Paris (Roberto Toro) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 ENS Ulm
 Paris (B. Cazelles)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit
 University of Oxford
 UK (J. Mena-Segovia) 	Massachusetts General Hospital
 Harvard University
 USA (R. Gupta) 	Department of Neurology
 Lariboisière Hospital
 Paris (Hugues Chabriat) 	Sainte-Anne Hospital
 Paris (Catherine Oppenheim
 Marie Sarazin) 	Kremlin-Bicêtre Hospital
 Paris (Emmanuelle Corruble
 Florence Gressier

 Caen University Hospital (Gaël Chételat
 Francis Eustache
 Béatrice Desgranges) 	Lille University Hospital (Christine Delmaire)   <strong>Local collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	CENIR MRI core facility (Stéphane Lehéricy
 Eric Bardinet

 Laurent Hugueville) 	CENIR Stereotaxy core facility (Sara Fernandez-Vidal) 	ICM/IHU Bioinformatics/biostatistics core facility (Ivan Moszer) 	Laboratoire d\'Imagerie Biomédicale (Habib Benali)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	IM2A / ICM Bruno Dubois\'s team (Bruno Dubois

 HDR) - "http://cogimage.dsi.cnrs.fr/perso/colliot/" >webpage</a> - "mailto: olivier.colliot@upmc.fr">email</a>  <ul> 	Didier Dormont - Professor of Neuroradiology (PU-PH)
 UPMC / AP-HP - "mailto: didier.dormont@psl.aphp.fr">email</a>   Researchers<ul> 	Mario Chavez - CNRS Researcher (CR1) - "mailto: mario.chavez@upmc.fr">email</a> 	Marie Chupin - CNRS Research Engineer (IR) - "mailto: marie.chupin@upmc.fr">email</a> 	Stanley Durrleman - INRIA Researcher - "https://who.rocq.inria.fr/Stanley.Durrleman/index.html" >webpage</a> - "mailto: stanley.durrleman@inria.fr">email</a>   Medical Faculty / Clinicians<ul> 	Claude Adam - Neurologist (PH)

 0),
 (444
 1
 '2014-03-11 17:06:21'
 '2014-03-11 16:06:21'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.  TO BE COMPLETED;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software (segmentation
 morphometry
 machine learning). We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> University of London
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	INRIA "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> (Jean-François Mangin
 Cyril Poupon
 Vincent Frouin
 Lucie Hertz-Pannier
 Jean-Baptiste Poline) 	Center for Magnetic Resonance Research
 University of Minnesota
 USA (Pierre-François Van de Moortele
 Tom Henry
 Kamil Ugurbil) 	Scientific Computing and Imaging ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/" >SCI</a>) Institute
 University of Utah
 USA ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/~gerig/" >Guido Gerig</a>
 "https://www.bioen.utah.edu/directory/profile.php?userID=252" >Sarang Joshi</a>
 "http://www.sci.utah.edu/~prastawa/" >Marcel Prastawa</a>) 	INRIA "https://www.irisa.fr/visages/" >Visages</a> ("http://www.irisa.fr/prive/barillot/" >Christian Barillot</a>) 	Laboratoire AMIS
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse (José Braga
 Jean Dumoncel) 	"https://www.pasteur.fr/en" >Institut Pasteur</a>
 Paris ("http://www.ura2182.cnrs-bellevue.fr/rtoro/" >Roberto Toro</a>) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 ENS Ulm
 Paris (B. Cazelles)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit
 University of Oxford
 UK (J. Mena-Segovia) 	Massachusetts General Hospital
 Harvard University
 USA (R. Gupta) 	Department of Neurology
 Lariboisière Hospital
 Paris (Hugues Chabriat) 	Sainte-Anne Hospital
 Paris (Catherine Oppenheim
 Marie Sarazin) 	Kremlin-Bicêtre Hospital
 Paris (Emmanuelle Corruble
 Florence Gressier
 Romain Colle) 	Bordeaux University Hospital (Carole Dufouil) 	Cycéron
 Caen University Hospital (Gaël Chételat
 Francis Eustache
 Béatrice Desgranges) 	Lille University Hospital (Christine Delmaire)   <strong>Local collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	CENIR MRI core facility (Stéphane Lehéricy
 Eric Bardinet
 Romain Valabrègue) 	CENIR MEG/EEG core facility (Nathalie George
 Denis Schwartz
 Laurent Hugueville) 	CENIR Stereotaxy core facility (Sara Fernandez-Vidal) 	ICM/IHU Bioinformatics/biostatistics core facility (Ivan Moszer) 	Laboratoire d\'Imagerie Biomédicale (Habib Benali)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	IM2A / ICM Bruno Dubois\'s team (Bruno Dubois
 Harald Hampel
 Stéphane Epelbaum) 	ICM Alexis Brice\'s team (Alexis Brice
 Isabelle Le Ber
 Christel Depienne) 	ICM Marie Vidailhet / Stéphane Lehéricy\'s team (Marie Vidailhet
 Stéphane Lehéricy
 Andreas Hartmann
 Yulia Worbe) 	ICM Richard Miles\'s team 	ICM Stéphane Charpier\'s team 	Department of Neuroradiology
 Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital '

 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Image3.jpg"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-46 alignleft" alt="Image3" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Image3-150x150.jpg" width="150" height="150" /></a>Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.  TO BE COMPLETED;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software (segmentation
 morphometry
 machine learning). We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research

 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> University of London
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	INRIA "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> (Jean-François Mangin
