 '2014-03-11 17:50:25'
 '2014-03-11 16:50:25'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.  TO BE COMPLETED;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software (segmentation
 morphometry
 machine learning). We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> University of London
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	INRIA "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> (Jean-François Mangin
 Cyril Poupon
 Vincent Frouin
 Lucie Hertz-Pannier
 Jean-Baptiste Poline) 	Center for Magnetic Resonance Research
 University of Minnesota
 USA (Pierre-François Van de Moortele
 Tom Henry
 Kamil Ugurbil) 	Scientific Computing and Imaging ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/" >SCI</a>) Institute
 University of Utah
 USA ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/~gerig/" >Guido Gerig</a>
 "https://www.bioen.utah.edu/directory/profile.php?userID=252" >Sarang Joshi</a>
 "http://www.sci.utah.edu/~prastawa/" >Marcel Prastawa</a>) 	INRIA "https://www.irisa.fr/visages/" >Visages</a> ("http://www.irisa.fr/prive/barillot/" >Christian Barillot</a>) 	Laboratoire AMIS
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse (José Braga
 Jean Dumoncel) 	"https://www.pasteur.fr/en" >Institut Pasteur</a>
 Paris ("http://www.ura2182.cnrs-bellevue.fr/rtoro/" >Roberto Toro</a>) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 ENS Ulm
 Paris (B. Cazelles)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit
 University of Oxford
 UK (J. Mena-Segovia) 	Massachusetts General Hospital
 Harvard University
 USA (R. Gupta) 	Department of Neurology
 Lariboisière Hospital
 Paris (Hugues Chabriat) 	Sainte-Anne Hospital
 Paris (Catherine Oppenheim
 Marie Sarazin) 	Kremlin-Bicêtre Hospital
 Paris (Emmanuelle Corruble
 Florence Gressier
 Romain Colle) 	Bordeaux University Hospital (Carole Dufouil) 	Cycéron
 Caen University Hospital (Gaël Chételat
 Francis Eustache
 Béatrice Desgranges) 	Lille University Hospital (Christine Delmaire)   <strong>Local collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	CENIR MRI core facility (Stéphane Lehéricy
 Eric Bardinet
 Romain Valabrègue) 	CENIR MEG/EEG core facility (Nathalie George
 Denis Schwartz
 Laurent Hugueville) 	CENIR Stereotaxy core facility (Sara Fernandez-Vidal) 	ICM/IHU Bioinformatics/biostatistics core facility (Ivan Moszer) 	Laboratoire d\'Imagerie Biomédicale (Habib Benali)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	IM2A / ICM Bruno Dubois\'s team (Bruno Dubois
 Harald Hampel
 Stéphane Epelbaum) 	ICM Alexis Brice\'s team (Alexis Brice
 Isabelle Le Ber
 Christel Depienne) 	ICM Marie Vidailhet / Stéphane Lehéricy\'s team (Marie Vidailhet
 Stéphane Lehéricy
 Andreas Hartmann
 Yulia Worbe) 	ICM Richard Miles\'s team 	ICM Stéphane Charpier\'s team 	Department of Neuroradiology
 Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital '

 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.  TO BE COMPLETED;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software (segmentation
 morphometry
 machine learning). We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> University of London
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	Inria "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> (Jean-François Mangin

 (457
 1
 '2014-03-11 19:03:45'
 '2014-03-11 18:03:45'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited.  TO BE COMPLETED;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software (segmentation
 morphometry
 machine learning). We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> University of London
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	Inria "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> (Jean-François Mangin
 Cyril Poupon
 Vincent Frouin
 Lucie Hertz-Pannier
 Jean-Baptiste Poline) 	Center for Magnetic Resonance Research
 University of Minnesota
 USA (Pierre-François Van de Moortele
 Tom Henry
 Kamil Ugurbil) 	Scientific Computing and Imaging ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/" >SCI</a>) Institute
 University of Utah
 USA ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/~gerig/" >Guido Gerig</a>
 "https://www.bioen.utah.edu/directory/profile.php?userID=252" >Sarang Joshi</a>
 "http://www.sci.utah.edu/~prastawa/" >Marcel Prastawa</a>) 	Inria "https://www.irisa.fr/visages/" >Visages</a> ("http://www.irisa.fr/prive/barillot/" >Christian Barillot</a>) 	Laboratoire AMIS
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse (José Braga
 Jean Dumoncel) 	"https://www.pasteur.fr/en" >Institut Pasteur</a>
 Paris ("http://www.ura2182.cnrs-bellevue.fr/rtoro/" >Roberto Toro</a>) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 ENS Ulm
 Paris (B. Cazelles)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit
 University of Oxford
 UK (J. Mena-Segovia) 	Massachusetts General Hospital
 Harvard University
 USA (R. Gupta) 	Department of Neurology
 Lariboisière Hospital
 Paris (Hugues Chabriat) 	Sainte-Anne Hospital
 Paris (Catherine Oppenheim
 Marie Sarazin) 	Kremlin-Bicêtre Hospital
 Paris (Emmanuelle Corruble
 Florence Gressier
 Romain Colle) 	Bordeaux University Hospital (Carole Dufouil) 	Cycéron
 Caen University Hospital (Gaël Chételat
 Francis Eustache
 Béatrice Desgranges) 	Lille University Hospital (Christine Delmaire)   <strong>Local collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	CENIR MRI core facility (Stéphane Lehéricy
 Eric Bardinet
 Romain Valabrègue) 	CENIR MEG/EEG core facility (Nathalie George
 Denis Schwartz
 Laurent Hugueville) 	CENIR Stereotaxy core facility (Sara Fernandez-Vidal) 	ICM/IHU Bioinformatics/biostatistics core facility (Ivan Moszer) 	Laboratoire d\'Imagerie Biomédicale (Habib Benali)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	IM2A / ICM Bruno Dubois\'s team (Bruno Dubois
 Harald Hampel
 Stéphane Epelbaum) 	ICM Alexis Brice\'s team (Alexis Brice
 Isabelle Le Ber
 Christel Depienne) 	ICM Marie Vidailhet / Stéphane Lehéricy\'s team (Marie Vidailhet
 Stéphane Lehéricy
 Andreas Hartmann
 Yulia Worbe) 	ICM Richard Miles\'s team 	ICM Stéphane Charpier\'s team 	Department of Neuroradiology
 Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital '

 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized

 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians

 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures

 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>

 '<h1>Most representative publications</h1> HERE : PUT LIST OF MOST REPRESENTATIVE PUBLICATIONS.  USE FOLLOWING FORMAT  <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Olivier</strong>  Cuingnet R

 682-696

 '<h1>Most representative publications</h1> HERE : PUT LIST OF MOST REPRESENTATIVE PUBLICATIONS.  USE FOLLOWING FORMAT  <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Olivier</strong>  Cuingnet R

 Glaunès JA

 '2014-03-13 10:45:54'
 '2014-03-13 09:45:54'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited. Our team aims at developing new statistical approaches to discover relevant patterns from such datasets and to integrate multimodal data from imaging and genomics. We also have a strong practical expertise in managing and analyzing massive multicenter datasets.  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	machine learning approaches to extract biomarkers 	multimodal analysis approaches for bridging imaging and genomics 	methodologies for multicenter neuroimaging datasets (see CATI project below);  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 ARAMIS is in charge of harmonization of MRI acquisitions
 image quality control and development of image analysis methods and software (segmentation
 morphometry
 machine learning). We have designed and implemented harmonized MRI protocols for nearly 30 imaging centers in France. We implement procedures for controlling image quality across centers and develop the corresponding software. Engineers further develop our segmentation and morphometry software
 to increase robustness and scalability.</p> &nbsp;  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >University of London</a>
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	Inria "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> ("http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique7" >Jean-François Mangin</a>
 "http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique74" >Cyril Poupon</a>

 USA ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/~gerig/" >Guido Gerig</a>
 "https://www.bioen.utah.edu/directory/profile.php?userID=252" >Sarang Joshi</a>
 "http://www.sci.utah.edu/~prastawa/" >Marcel Prastawa</a>) 	Inria "https://www.irisa.fr/visages/" >Visages</a> ("http://www.irisa.fr/prive/barillot/" >Christian Barillot</a>) 	"http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/index.php?clear=1" >Laboratoire AMIS</a>
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse ("http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/content.php?itemId=6&amp;id=6" >José Braga</a>
 "http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/content.php?itemId=115&amp;id=6&amp;cur=0&amp;date&amp;manager&amp;categPath&amp;" >Jean Dumoncel</a>) 	"https://www.pasteur.fr/en" >Institut Pasteur</a>
 Paris ("http://www.ura2182.cnrs-bellevue.fr/rtoro/" >Roberto Toro</a>) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 "http://www.ens.fr/?lang=en" >ENS</a> Ulm
 Paris ("http://www.biologie.ens.fr/~cazelles/bernard/Welcome.html" >B. Cazelles</a>)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.mrc.ox.ac.uk/" >Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit</a>
 University of Oxford
 UK ("http://www.mrc.ox.ac.uk/people/dr-juan-mena-segovia" >J. Mena-Segovia</a>) 	"http://nmmiweb.mgh.harvard.edu/CAMIS/" >Center for Advanced Medical Imaging Sciences</a>

 USA ("http://nmmiweb.mgh.harvard.edu/CAMIS/?page_id=1604" >R. Gupta</a>) 	Department of Neurology

 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited. Our team aims at developing new statistical approaches to discover relevant patterns from such datasets and to integrate multimodal data from imaging and genomics. We also have a strong practical expertise in managing and analyzing massive multicenter datasets.  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	machine learning approaches to extract biomarkers 	multimodal analysis approaches for bridging imaging and genomics 	methodologies for multicenter neuroimaging datasets (see CATI project below);  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 our team is particularly involved in:</p>  <ul> 	standardization of MRI acquisitions 	quality control of MRI scans 	processing of anatomical MRI data 	development of new tools for image analysis (segmentation
 morphometry)  <p style="text-align: justify;"></p> <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >University of London</a>
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	Inria "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> ("http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique7" >Jean-François Mangin</a>
 "http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique74" >Cyril Poupon</a>
 "http://www.eu-aims.eu/the-group/consortium/neurospin-cea/" >Vincent Frouin</a>
 "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin/recherche/unites-de-recherche/unite-de-recherche-en-neuroimagerie-applicative-clinique-et-translationnelle-uniact" >Lucie Hertz-Pannier</a>
 "http://www.incf.org/community/people/jbpoline/person_view" >Jean-Baptiste Poline</a>) 	"https://www.cmrr.umn.edu/" >Center for Magnetic Resonance Research</a>
 University of Minnesota
 USA ("http://www.cmrr.umn.edu/facultystaff/pfvdm.shtml" >Pierre-François Van de Moortele</a>
 Tom Henry
 "http://www.neurosci.umn.edu/faculty/ugurbil.html" >Kamil Ugurbil</a>) 	Scientific Computing and Imaging ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/" >SCI</a>) Institute
 University of Utah
 USA ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/~gerig/" >Guido Gerig</a>
 "https://www.bioen.utah.edu/directory/profile.php?userID=252" >Sarang Joshi</a>
 "http://www.sci.utah.edu/~prastawa/" >Marcel Prastawa</a>) 	Inria "https://www.irisa.fr/visages/" >Visages</a> ("http://www.irisa.fr/prive/barillot/" >Christian Barillot</a>) 	"http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/index.php?clear=1" >Laboratoire AMIS</a>
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse ("http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/content.php?itemId=6&amp;id=6" >José Braga</a>
 "http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/content.php?itemId=115&amp;id=6&amp;cur=0&amp;date&amp;manager&amp;categPath&amp;" >Jean Dumoncel</a>) 	"https://www.pasteur.fr/en" >Institut Pasteur</a>
 Paris ("http://www.ura2182.cnrs-bellevue.fr/rtoro/" >Roberto Toro</a>) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 "http://www.ens.fr/?lang=en" >ENS</a> Ulm
 Paris ("http://www.biologie.ens.fr/~cazelles/bernard/Welcome.html" >B. Cazelles</a>)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.mrc.ox.ac.uk/" >Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit</a>
 University of Oxford
 UK ("http://www.mrc.ox.ac.uk/people/dr-juan-mena-segovia" >J. Mena-Segovia</a>) 	"http://nmmiweb.mgh.harvard.edu/CAMIS/" >Center for Advanced Medical Imaging Sciences</a>
 Massachusetts General Hospital

 USA ("http://nmmiweb.mgh.harvard.edu/CAMIS/?page_id=1604" >R. Gupta</a>) 	Department of Neurology

 Paris ("http://cervco.aphp.fr/equipe/HChabriat.htm" >Hugues Chabriat</a>) 	"http://www.ch-sainte-anne.fr/" >Sainte-Anne Hospital</a>
 Paris ("http://scholar.google.fr/citations?user=CBzHpxEAAAAJ&amp;hl=fr" >Catherine Oppenheim</a>
 Marie Sarazin) 	Kremlin-Bicêtre Hospital
 Paris (Emmanuelle Corruble

 '2014-03-13 10:50:23'

 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited. Our team aims at developing new statistical approaches to discover relevant patterns from such datasets and to integrate multimodal data from imaging and genomics. We also have a strong practical expertise in managing and analyzing massive multicenter datasets.  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	machine learning approaches to extract biomarkers 	multimodal analysis approaches for bridging imaging and genomics 	methodologies for multicenter neuroimaging datasets (see CATI project below);  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 our team is particularly involved in:</p>  <ul> 	standardization of MRI acquisitions 	quality control of MRI scans 	processing of anatomical MRI data 	development of new tools for image analysis (segmentation
 morphometry);  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune

 ' March 15: ARAMIS in the newsINRIA official website features the research of the ARAMIS Lab on the occasion of the French "Brain week". Full article "http://www.inria.fr/centre/paris/actualites/quand-les-statistiques-percent-les-mysteres-du-cerveau">here</a> (in French)
 and more pics "http://phototheque.inria.fr/phototheque/category/750">there</a>. Enjoy and Share!  Jan 8: Congratulations to Pietro Gori!who successfully defended his PhD today about "Statistical models to learn the structural organisation of neural circuits from multimodal brain images
 with application to Gilles de la Tourette syndrome".  Dec 21: Congratulations to Takoua Kaaouana!who successfully defended her PhD today on the "detection and characterization of brain micro-bleeds with applications on mutli-centric clinical data".  Dec 4: Congratulations to Stanley Durrleman!who won an ERC Starting Grant from the "https://erc.europa.eu/">European Research Council</a>.  Nov 13: New postdoc position opened!The ARAMIS lab recruits <strong>high-profile researchers
 data scientists and engineers</strong> with a solid background in statistical learning
 data science and/or medical imaging. More info "https://www.aramislab.fr/files/job_offers/JobOffer_ARAMIS.pdf">here</a> or in the "https://www.aramislab.fr/job-offers/">job offer section</a>!  Nov 13: New position opened for a software developer!We recruit a talented software developer to develop a product for the construction of virtual models of brain disease progression and its validation in a clinical environment. More info here or in the "https://www.aramislab.fr/job-offers/">job offer section</a>!<strong> </strong>  Oct 23: New PhD position opened!We are looking for highly motivated students with a strong background in statistical learning and data analysis. The PhD will be about the development of novel learning methods for the statistical exploitation of multimodal longitudinal data sets. More info "https://www.aramislab.fr/files/job_offers/PhD_Inria_ICM.pdf">here</a> or in the "https://www.aramislab.fr/job-offers/">job offer section</a>!  Sept 27: ARAMIS in the news!Aramis was broadcasted yesterday in the French TV newsmagazine  Zone Interdite</em> (M6) on Sunday prime time. The report was about the brain-computer interface set up at our "http://cenir.org/fr/lequipe-meg-eeg.html" >EEG/MEG Centre</a>. The journalist managed to write the word "Fascinant!" using only her brain. Congratulations Mario
 Fabrizio
 Fanny
 Laurent and Xavier! Well done!  See the "https://www.facebook.com/zoneinterditem6/videos/vb.112189452160359/955692764476686/?type=2&amp;theater" >MakingOf</a> or the "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BmGiaPG9cnA" >Report</a>;  Conference IPMI 2015 - Information Processing in Medical Imaging<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : 28th June - 3rd July 2015 <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Location : Sabhal Mor Ostaig College
 Isle of Skye
 Scotland <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Description: One of the preeminent international forums for presentation of leading-edge research in the medical imaging field. "http://ipmi2015.cs.ucl.ac.uk" >link</a> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Comments: The Aramis Lab participated with two works selected respectively for oral and poster presentation. The poster was then chosen by the participants for an oral presentation. Bravo Jean-Baptiste! <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Poster: J.-B. Schiratti
 S. Allassonnière
 O. Colliot and S. Durrleman - "https://hal-polytechnique.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01163213/document" > A Mixed­ Effect Model with Time Reparametrization for Longitudinal Univariate Manifold-valued Data</em></a> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Oral : P. Gori
 O. Colliot
 L. Marrakchi-Kacem
 Y. Worbe
 S. Lecomte
 C. Poupon
 A. Hartmann
 N. Ayache and S.  (528
 1
 '2014-03-13 15:45:42'
 '2014-03-13 14:45:42'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited. Our team aims at developing new statistical approaches to discover relevant patterns from such datasets and to integrate multimodal data from imaging and genomics. We also have a strong practical expertise in managing and analyzing massive multicenter datasets.  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	machine learning approaches to extract biomarkers 	multimodal analysis approaches for bridging imaging and genomics 	methodologies for multicenter neuroimaging datasets (see CATI project below);  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 our team is particularly involved in:</p>  <ul> 	standardization of MRI acquisitions 	quality control of MRI scans 	processing of anatomical MRI data 	development of new tools for image analysis (segmentation
 morphometry);  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >University of London</a>
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	Inria "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> ("http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique7" >Jean-François Mangin</a>
 "http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique74" >Cyril Poupon</a>
 Alexandre Vignaud
 "http://www.eu-aims.eu/the-group/consortium/neurospin-cea/" >Vincent Frouin</a>
 "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin/recherche/unites-de-recherche/unite-de-recherche-en-neuroimagerie-applicative-clinique-et-translationnelle-uniact" >Lucie Hertz-Pannier</a>
 "http://www.incf.org/community/people/jbpoline/person_view" >Jean-Baptiste Poline</a>) 	"https://www.cmrr.umn.edu/" >Center for Magnetic Resonance Research</a>
 University of Minnesota
 USA ("http://www.cmrr.umn.edu/facultystaff/pfvdm.shtml" >Pierre-François Van de Moortele</a>
 Tom Henry
 "http://www.neurosci.umn.edu/faculty/ugurbil.html" >Kamil Ugurbil</a>) 	Scientific Computing and Imaging ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/" >SCI</a>) Institute
 University of Utah
 USA ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/~gerig/" >Guido Gerig</a>
 "https://www.bioen.utah.edu/directory/profile.php?userID=252" >Sarang Joshi</a>
 "http://www.sci.utah.edu/~prastawa/" >Marcel Prastawa</a>) 	Inria "https://www.irisa.fr/visages/" >Visages</a> ("http://www.irisa.fr/prive/barillot/" >Christian Barillot</a>) 	"http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/index.php?clear=1" >Laboratoire AMIS</a>
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse ("http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/content.php?itemId=6&amp;id=6" >José Braga</a>
 "http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/content.php?itemId=115&amp;id=6&amp;cur=0&amp;date&amp;manager&amp;categPath&amp;" >Jean Dumoncel</a>) 	"https://www.pasteur.fr/en" >Institut Pasteur</a>
 Paris ("http://www.ura2182.cnrs-bellevue.fr/rtoro/" >Roberto Toro</a>) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 "http://www.ens.fr/?lang=en" >ENS</a> Ulm
 Paris ("http://www.biologie.ens.fr/~cazelles/bernard/Welcome.html" >B. Cazelles</a>)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.mrc.ox.ac.uk/" >Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit</a>
 University of Oxford
 UK ("http://www.mrc.ox.ac.uk/people/dr-juan-mena-segovia" >J. Mena-Segovia</a>) 	"http://nmmiweb.mgh.harvard.edu/CAMIS/" >Center for Advanced Medical Imaging Sciences</a>
 Massachusetts General Hospital
 Harvard University
 USA ("http://nmmiweb.mgh.harvard.edu/CAMIS/?page_id=1604" >R. Gupta</a>) 	Department of Neurology
 "http://ghparis10.aphp.fr/" >Lariboisière Hospital</a>
 Paris ("http://cervco.aphp.fr/equipe/HChabriat.htm" >Hugues Chabriat</a>) 	"http://www.ch-sainte-anne.fr/" >Sainte-Anne Hospital</a>
 Paris ("http://scholar.google.fr/citations?user=CBzHpxEAAAAJ&amp;hl=fr" >Catherine Oppenheim</a>
 Marie Sarazin) 	Kremlin-Bicêtre Hospital
 Paris (Emmanuelle Corruble

 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited. Our team aims at developing new statistical approaches to discover relevant patterns from such datasets and to integrate multimodal data from imaging and genomics. We also have a strong practical expertise in managing and analyzing massive multicenter datasets.  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	machine learning approaches to extract biomarkers 	multimodal analysis approaches for bridging imaging and genomics 	methodologies for multicenter neuroimaging datasets (see CATI project below);  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 our team is particularly involved in:</p>  <ul> 	standardization of MRI acquisitions 	quality control of MRI scans 	processing of anatomical MRI data 	development of new tools for image analysis (segmentation
 morphometry);  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >University of London</a>
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	Inria "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> ("http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique7" >Jean-François Mangin</a>
 "http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique74" >Cyril Poupon</a>

 'https://www.aramislab.fr/?p=535'

 'revision'
