 0),
 (537
 1
 '2014-03-14 09:50:32'
 '2014-03-14 08:50:32'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited. Our team aims at developing new statistical approaches to discover relevant patterns from such datasets and to integrate multimodal data from imaging and genomics. We also have a strong practical expertise in managing and analyzing massive multicenter datasets.  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	machine learning approaches to extract biomarkers 	multimodal analysis approaches for bridging imaging and genomics 	methodologies for multicenter neuroimaging datasets (see CATI project below);  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 our team is particularly involved in:</p>  <ul> 	standardization of MRI acquisitions 	quality control of MRI scans 	processing of anatomical MRI data 	development of new tools for image analysis (segmentation
 morphometry);  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >University of London</a>
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	Inria "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> ("http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique7" >Jean-François Mangin</a>
 "http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique74" >Cyril Poupon</a>

 University of Utah
 USA ("http://www.sci.utah.edu/~gerig/" >Guido Gerig</a>
 "https://www.bioen.utah.edu/directory/profile.php?userID=252" >Sarang Joshi</a>
 "http://www.sci.utah.edu/~prastawa/" >Marcel Prastawa</a>) 	Inria "https://www.irisa.fr/visages/" >Visages</a> ("http://www.irisa.fr/prive/barillot/" >Christian Barillot</a>) 	"http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/index.php?clear=1" >Laboratoire AMIS</a>
 Université Paul Sabatier
 Toulouse ("http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/content.php?itemId=6&amp;id=6" >José Braga</a>
 "http://www.anthropobiologie.fr/content.php?itemId=115&amp;id=6&amp;cur=0&amp;date&amp;manager&amp;categPath&amp;" >Jean Dumoncel</a>) 	"https://www.pasteur.fr/en" >Institut Pasteur</a>
 Paris ("http://www.ura2182.cnrs-bellevue.fr/rtoro/" >Roberto Toro</a>) 	Department of Ecology and Evolution
 "http://www.ens.fr/?lang=en" >ENS</a> Ulm
 Paris ("http://www.biologie.ens.fr/~cazelles/bernard/Welcome.html" >B. Cazelles</a>)   Medical collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.mrc.ox.ac.uk/" >Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit</a>
 University of Oxford
 UK ("http://www.mrc.ox.ac.uk/people/dr-juan-mena-segovia" >J. Mena-Segovia</a>) 	"http://nmmiweb.mgh.harvard.edu/CAMIS/" >Center for Advanced Medical Imaging Sciences</a>
 Massachusetts General Hospital
 Harvard University
 USA ("http://nmmiweb.mgh.harvard.edu/CAMIS/?page_id=1604" >R. Gupta</a>) 	Department of Neurology
 "http://ghparis10.aphp.fr/" >Lariboisière Hospital</a>
 Paris ("http://cervco.aphp.fr/equipe/HChabriat.htm" >Hugues Chabriat</a>) 	"http://www.ch-sainte-anne.fr/" >Sainte-Anne Hospital</a>
 Paris ("http://scholar.google.fr/citations?user=CBzHpxEAAAAJ&amp;hl=fr" >Catherine Oppenheim</a>
 Marie Sarazin) 	"http://hopital-bicetre.aphp.fr/" >Kremlin-Bicêtre Hospital</a>
 Paris ("http://www.u669.idf.inserm.fr/page.asp?page=2418" >Emmanuelle Corruble</a>

 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures

 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals.  clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets

 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited. Our team aims at developing new statistical approaches to discover relevant patterns from such datasets and to integrate multimodal data from imaging and genomics. We also have a strong practical expertise in managing and analyzing massive multicenter datasets.  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	machine learning approaches to extract biomarkers 	multimodal analysis approaches for bridging imaging and genomics 	methodologies for multicenter neuroimaging datasets (see CATI project below);  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI

 (539
 1
 '2014-03-14 16:43:24'
 '2014-03-14 15:43:24'
 ' <strong>Context and general aim</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">Studying brain structure and function requires the integration of multiple levels of organization
 operating at different spatial and temporal scales. The integration of such a large variety of data is now possible thanks to the recent emergence of large-scale multimodal datasets. In this context
 mathematical and computational approaches are becoming increasingly important because: <i>i)</i> they provide formalized
 operational and flexible frameworks from integrating multiple processes and scales; <i>ii)</i> they allow automated processing and analysis of massive datasets. These approaches can then be used to find biomarkers of a disease
 for genotype/phenotype correlations
 or to characterize functional responses for instance.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The overall aim of our team is to design new computational and mathematical approaches for studying brain structure (based on anatomical and diffusion MRI) and functional connectivity (based on EEG
 MEG and intracerebral recordings).</strong> The goal is to transform raw unstructured images and signals into formalized
 operational models such as geometric models of brain structures
 statistical population models
 graph-theoretic models of brain connectivity...</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">These new approaches are applied to brain pathologies
 in close collaboration with medical researchers and clinicians
 in order to: <i>i)</i> better understand their pathophysiological mechanisms; <i>ii)</i> design new biomarkers for diagnosis
 prognosis and tracking disease progression.</p> &nbsp;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling brain structure from anatomical and diffusion MRI</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Computational anatomy aims at building statistical models of the structure of the human brain. This endeavor requires addressing the following methodological issues: i) the extraction of geometrical objects (anatomical structures
 lesions
 white matter tracks...) from anatomical and diffusion-weighted MRI; ii) the design of a coherent mathematical framework to model anatomical shapes and compare them across individuals. These approaches can then be used to perform statistical studies allowing to characterize the anatomical alterations associated to a given neurological disorder
 to study their progression and their correlation with symptoms and cognitive deficits.</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within this area
 our main research topics are :</p>  <ul> 	automatic methods to segment anatomical structures and lesions 	statistical shape models based on diffeomorphic deformations 	longitudinal models to study the progression of brain alterations over time 	7T MRI to study the internal structure of the hippocampus;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Modeling dynamical brain networks</strong>  Functional imaging techniques (EEG
 MEG and fMRI) allow characterizing the interactions between the activities of different brain areas
 leading to understand how cognitive processes and pathological brain states emerge from an interplay of structure and function. Our research aims to provide a coherent theoretical framework for analyzing and modeling brain dynamics in terms of time-varying functional connectivity networks. Such approaches are applied to further our understanding of abnormal connectivity during some dynamical brain diseases (e.g. Epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease) or during natural recovery from brain damage (e.g. Stroke recovery).  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	complex networks theory to characterize connectivity patterns 	causality analysis 	analysis of time-varying networks 	brain computer interfaces for clinical applications;  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">Integrating multimodal data (neuroimaging
 genomics
 clinical data)</strong>  Large-scale multimodal datasets
 combining neuroimaging
 clinical data and different types of "omics" data (genetics
 transcriptomics...) are becoming a pivotal tool for neuroscience research. These datasets are complex
 high-dimensional and often heterogeneous
 and thus require the development of new methodologies to be fully exploited. Our team aims at developing new statistical approaches to discover relevant patterns from such datasets and to integrate multimodal data from imaging and genomics. We also have a strong practical expertise in managing and analyzing massive multicenter datasets.  Within this area
 our main research topics are: <ul> 	machine learning approaches to extract biomarkers 	multimodal analysis approaches for bridging imaging and genomics 	methodologies for multicenter neuroimaging datasets (see CATI project below);  <strong><span style="color: #333333; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\',arial,sans-serif; font-size: 20px; line-height: normal;">CATI project: managing multicenter neuroimaging studies</strong> <p style="text-align: justify;">Our team is strongly involved in the "http://cati-neuroimaging.com/">CATI project</a> (PI: J-F Mangin). CATI is a joint project with "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/en/institutes/institute-of-biomedical-imaging-i2bm/departments/neurospin-neurospin">Neurospin</a>
 "http://www.imed.jussieu.fr/">LIF</a>
 "http://www.cenir.org/">CENIR</a> and "http://fondation-recherche-alzheimer.com/375/linstitut-de-la-memoire-et-de-la-maladie-dalzheimer-im2a/">IM2A</a>
 funded by the "http://www.plan-alzheimer.gouv.fr/-44-measures-.html">Alzheimer Plan</a> which aims at building a national platform for multicenter studies. CATI aims at mutualizing all the resources required to perform multi-center neuroimaging studies. CATI services cover harmonization of image acquisition
 quality control
 monitoring
 databasing as well as data analysis. CATI is already in charge of the imaging core of more than fifteen large French multicenter studies in various disorders
 including several therapeutic trials and the national cohort of the French Alzheimer plan (2300 subjects).</p> <p style="text-align: justify;">Within CATI
 our team is particularly involved in:</p>  <ul> 	standardization of MRI acquisitions 	quality control of MRI scans 	processing of anatomical MRI data 	development of software for structural MRI analysis 	research on new image analysis approaches (segmentation
 morphometry
 machine learning);  <span style="color: #008c9e; font-family: \'Pontano Sans\'
 arial
 sans-serif; font-size: 23px; line-height: normal;">Collaborations  <strong>External collaborations</strong> Methodological collaborations  <ul> 	"http://www.ens-cachan.fr/" >ENS de Cachan</a> ("http://atrouve.perso.math.cnrs.fr/" >Alain Trouvé</a>) 	"http://www.parisdescartes.fr/" >Université Paris-Descartes</a> ("http://www.mi.parisdescartes.fr/~glaunes/" >Joan Glaunès</a>) 	Center for Applied Medical Research
 Pampelune
 Spain (M. Valencia) 	Departement of Physics. "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >Queen Mary</a> "http://ph.qmul.ac.uk/" >University of London</a>
 UK ("http://www.maths.qmul.ac.uk/~latora/" >Vito Latora</a>) 	Inria "https://team.inria.fr/asclepios/" >Asclepios</a> ("http://www-sop.inria.fr/members/Nicholas.Ayache/ayache.html" >Nicholas Ayache</a>) 	CEA "http://www-dsv.cea.fr/dsv/instituts/institut-d-imagerie-biomedicale-i2bm/services/neurospin-neurospin" >Neurospin</a> ("http://www.lnao.fr/spip.php?rubrique7" >Jean-François Mangin</a>

 ' <img class=" wp-image-61 aligncenter" alt="Picture_Aramis" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Picture_Aramis-1024x578.jpg" width="819" height="462" /> <span style="color: #000000;">Direction<ul> 	Olivier Colliot - CNRS Researcher (CR1
 HDR) - "http://cogimage.dsi.cnrs.fr/perso/colliot/" >webpage</a> - olivier.colliot@upmc.fr  <ul> 	Didier Dormont - Professor of Neuroradiology (PU-PH)
 UPMC / AP-HP - "mailto: didier.dormont@psl.aphp.fr">didier.dormont@psl.aphp.fr</a>   Researchers<ul> 	Mario Chavez - CNRS Researcher (CR1) - "mailto: mario.chavez@upmc.fr">mario.chavez@upmc.fr</a> 	Marie Chupin - CNRS Research Engineer (IR) - "mailto: marie.chupin@upmc.fr">marie.chupin@upmc.fr</a> 	Stanley Durrleman - Inria Researcher - "https://who.rocq.inria.fr/Stanley.Durrleman/index.html" >webpage</a> - "mailto: stanley.durrleman@inria.fr">stanley.durrleman@inria.fr</a>   Medical Faculty / Clinicians<ul> 	Claude Adam - Neurologist (PH)

 UPMC / AP-HP - "mailto: sophie.dupont@psl.aphp.fr" >sophie.dupont@psl.aphp.fr</a> 	Damien Galanaud - Professor of Neuroradiology (PU-PH)
 UPMC / AP-HP - "mailto: damien.galanaud@icm-institute.org" >damien.galanaud@icm-institute.org</a> 	Dominique Hasboun - Associate Professor of Neuroanatomy (MCU)

 '<strong>If you are interested in joining the team (with respect to any of our research topics)
 do not hesitate to send us an e-mail stating your field of interest and a CV. We may have other open positions than those advertised below. </strong>You can directly contact one of the "https://www.aramislab.fr/?page_id=4" >permanent researchers</a> of the team
 or the "mailto: olivier.colliot@upmc.fr" >head</a> of the team for a general inquiry. Our team is pluridisciplinary and we welcome applicants with different profiles and expertises (computer science
 electrical engineering
 neuroimaging
 neuroscience
 medicine...). <h1><span style="font-size: 20px;">Postdocs</h1> <ul> 	"http://www.inria.fr/en/institute/recruitment/offers/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/campaign-2014/(view)/details.html?id=PNGFK026203F3VBQB6G68LOE1&amp;ContractType=4546&amp;LG=EN&amp;Resultsperpage=20&amp;nPostingID=8265&amp;nPostingTargetID=13985&amp;option=52&amp;sort=DESC&amp;nDepartmentID=19" >Shape analysis of brain structures using 7T MRI</a>   -   <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 12 to 24 months  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: around november 2014 (possibility to start earlier)   Master Internships /  Stages de Master</em><ul> 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/stage_7T.pdf" >Anatomie computationnelle de la structure interne de l\'hippocampe à partir d\'IRM 7 Tesla à très haute résolution spatiale</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/stage_classification.pdf" >Automatic classification of patients with Alzheimer\'s disease from Magnetic Resonance Imaging data</a>   - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible   Others<ul> 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/CDD_CATI_7T_ARC.pdf" >ARC neuroimagerie</a> - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 6 months - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: May 2014   &nbsp;'

 ' March 15: ARAMIS in the news</h2>\nINRIA official website features the research of the ARAMIS Lab on the occasion of the French "Brain week". Full article "http://www.inria.fr/centre/paris/actualites/quand-les-statistiques-percent-les-mysteres-du-cerveau">here</a> (in French)
 and more pics there. Enjoy and Share!\n Jan 8: Congratulations to Pietro Gori!</h2>\nwho successfully defended his PhD today about "Statistical models to learn the structural organisation of neural circuits from multimodal brain images
 with application to Gilles de la Tourette syndrome".\n Dec 21: Congratulations to Takoua Kaaouana!</h2>\nwho successfully defended her PhD today on the "detection and characterization of brain micro-bleeds with applications on mutli-centric clinical data".\n Dec 4: Congratulations to Stanley Durrleman!</h2>\nwho won an ERC Starting Grant from the "https://erc.europa.eu/">European Research Council</a>.\n Nov 13: New postdoc position opened!</h2>\nThe ARAMIS lab recruits <strong>high-profile researchers
 data scientists and engineers</strong> with a solid background in statistical learning
 data science and/or medical imaging. More info "https://www.aramislab.fr/files/job_offers/JobOffer_ARAMIS.pdf">here</a> or in the "https://www.aramislab.fr/job-offers/">job offer section</a>!\n Nov 13: New position opened for a software developer!</h2>\nWe recruit a talented software developer to develop a product for the construction of virtual models of brain disease progression and its validation in a clinical environment. More info here or in the "https://www.aramislab.fr/job-offers/">job offer section</a>!<strong>\n</strong>\n Oct 23: New PhD position opened!</h2>\nWe are looking for highly motivated students with a strong background in statistical learning and data analysis. The PhD will be about the development of novel learning methods for the statistical exploitation of multimodal longitudinal data sets. More info "https://www.aramislab.fr/files/job_offers/PhD_Inria_ICM.pdf">here</a> or in the "https://www.aramislab.fr/job-offers/">job offer section</a>!\n Sept 27: ARAMIS in the news!</h2>\nAramis was broadcasted yesterday in the French TV newsmagazine  Zone Interdite</em> (M6) on Sunday prime time. The report was about the brain-computer interface set up at our "http://cenir.org/fr/lequipe-meg-eeg.html" >EEG/MEG Centre</a>. The journalist managed to write the word "Fascinant!" using only her brain. Congratulations Mario
 Fabrizio
 Fanny
 Laurent and Xavier! Well done!\n\nSee the "https://www.facebook.com/zoneinterditem6/videos/vb.112189452160359/955692764476686/?type=2&amp;theater" >MakingOf</a> or the "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BmGiaPG9cnA" >Report</a>\n\n&nbsp;\n Conference IPMI 2015 - Information Processing in Medical Imaging</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : 28th June - 3rd July 2015\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Location : Sabhal Mor Ostaig College
 Isle of Skye
 Scotland\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Description: One of the preeminent international forums for presentation of leading-edge research in the medical imaging field. "http://ipmi2015.cs.ucl.ac.uk" >link</a>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Comments: The Aramis Lab participated with two works selected respectively for oral and poster presentation. The poster was then chosen by the participants for an oral presentation. Bravo Jean-Baptiste!\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Poster: J.-B. Schiratti
 S. Allassonnière
 O. Colliot and S. Durrleman - "https://hal-polytechnique.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01163213/document" > A Mixed­ Effect Model with Time Reparametrization for Longitudinal Univariate Manifold-valued Data</em></a>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Oral : P. Gori
 O. Colliot
 L. Marrakchi-Kacem
 Y. Worbe
 S. Lecomte
 C. Poupon
 A. Hartmann
 N. Ayache and S. Durrleman -  "https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01142628/document" >Joint Morphometry of Fiber Tracts and Gray Matter structures using Double Diffeomorphisms</a></em>\n\n&nbsp;\n Conference OHBM 2015 - Organization for Human Brain Mapping</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : June 14th - 18th 2015\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Location : Honolulu
 Hawaii
 USA\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Description: It is the primary international organization dedicated to using neuroimaging to discover the organization of the human brain. "http://www.humanbrainmapping.org/" >link</a>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Comments: The Aramis Lab has massively participated with 14 posters and a seminary talk of our team leader Olivier during the full-day course “Pattern Recognition for NeuroImaging”. "https://www.aramislab.fr/ohbm-2015/" >More...</a>\n\n&nbsp;\n Research Highlights - IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Authors: Fabrizio De Vico Fallani et al.\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Title: Hierarchy of Neural Organization in the Embryonic Spinal Cord: Granger-Causality Graph Analysis of In Vivo Calcium Imaging Data\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Journal: IEEE Transaction Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
 23
 2015\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Link: "http://tnsre.embs.org/2015/05/06/hierarchy-of-neural-organization-in-the-embryonic-spinal-cord-granger-causality-graph-analysis-of-in-vivo-calcium-imaging-data/" >Paper</a>\n\n&nbsp;\n Seminar - Denis Le Bihan - May 18th 2015</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : May 18th
 2015 at 11:00am\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Speaker : Denis Le Bihan (Neurospin
 CEA)\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Title: Diffusion MRI: What water tells us about the brain\n\n&nbsp;\n Seminar - Ron Kikinis - May 11th 2015</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : May 11th
 2015 at 11:00am\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Speaker : Ron Kikinis (Harvard Medical School)\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Title: Medical Image Computing\n\n&nbsp;\n Seminar - Daniel Rueckert - March 23rd 2015</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : March 23rd
 2015 at 11:00am\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Speaker : Daniel Rueckert (Imperial College London)\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Title: Learning clinically useful information from brain images\n\n&nbsp;\n Thesis Defense - Claire Cury - Febrary 12th 2015</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : February 12th
 2015 at 14:30\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Phd student : Claire Cury\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Title: Analyse statistique de la variabilité anatomique de l\'hippocampe à partir de grandes populations.\n\n&nbsp;\n Seminar - Nicholas Ayache - February 9th 2015</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : February 9th
 2015 at 11:00am\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Speaker : Nicholas Ayache (Inria
 Sophia-Antipolis)\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Title: Medical Image Computing: towards a personalized Digital Patient\n\n&nbsp;\n Seminar - Marc Modat - January 29th 2015</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : January 29th
 2015 at 10:30am\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Speaker : Marc Modat (University College London)\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Title: Medical image analysis approaches for imaging biomarker development\n\n&nbsp;\n Seminar - Jean-François Mangin - October 20th 2014</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : October 20th
 2014 at 11:00am\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Speaker : Jean-François Mangin (CEA)\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Title: Turning shapes into biomarkers\n\n&nbsp;\n Seminar - Sophie Achard - October 9th 2014</h2>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Date : October 9th
 2014 at 11:30am\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Speaker : Sophie Achard (GIPSA Labs

 '<strong>If you are interested in joining the team (with respect to any of our research topics)
 do not hesitate to send us an e-mail stating your field of interest and a CV. We may have other open positions than those advertised below. </strong>You can directly contact one of the "https://www.aramislab.fr/?page_id=4" >permanent researchers</a> of the team
 or the "mailto:olivier.colliot@upmc.fr">head</a> of the team for a general inquiry. Our team is pluridisciplinary and we welcome applicants with different profiles and expertises (computer science
 electrical engineering
 neuroimaging
 neuroscience
 medicine...). <h1><span style="font-size: 20px;">Postdocs</h1> <ul> 	"http://www.inria.fr/en/institute/recruitment/offers/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/campaign-2014/(view)/details.html?id=PNGFK026203F3VBQB6G68LOE1&amp;ContractType=4546&amp;LG=EN&amp;Resultsperpage=20&amp;nPostingID=8265&amp;nPostingTargetID=13985&amp;option=52&amp;sort=DESC&amp;nDepartmentID=19" >Shape analysis of brain structures using 7T MRI</a>   -   <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 12 to 24 months  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: around november 2014 (possibility to start earlier)   Master Internships /  Stages de Master</em><ul> 	"files/job_offers/stage_7T.pdf" >Anatomie computationnelle de la structure interne de l\'hippocampe à partir d\'IRM 7 Tesla à très haute résolution spatiale</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible 	"files/job_offers/stage_classification.pdf" >Automatic classification of patients with Alzheimer\'s disease from Magnetic Resonance Imaging data</a>  - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible   Other positions &nbsp;'

 do not hesitate to send us an e-mail stating your field of interest and a CV. We may have other open positions than those advertised below. </strong>You can directly contact one of the "https://www.aramislab.fr/?page_id=4" >permanent researchers</a> of the team
 or the "mailto:olivier.colliot@upmc.fr">head</a> of the team for a general inquiry. Our team is pluridisciplinary and we welcome applicants with different profiles and expertises (computer science
 electrical engineering
 neuroimaging

 medicine...). <h1><span style="font-size: 20px;">Postdocs</h1> <ul> 	"http://www.inria.fr/en/institute/recruitment/offers/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/post-doctoral-research-fellowships/campaign-2014/(view)/details.html?id=PNGFK026203F3VBQB6G68LOE1&amp;ContractType=4546&amp;LG=EN&amp;Resultsperpage=20&amp;nPostingID=8265&amp;nPostingTargetID=13985&amp;option=52&amp;sort=DESC&amp;nDepartmentID=19" >Shape analysis of brain structures using 7T MRI</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 12 to 24 months  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: around november 2014 (possibility to start earlier) 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/joboffer_anne.pdf" >Histological MR Imaging of proteinopathies at 11.7T</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Duration: 24 months  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: October 2014 (starting  date  can be modulated)   Master Internships /  Stages de Master</em><ul> 	"files/job_offers/stage_7T.pdf" >Anatomie computationnelle de la structure interne de l\'hippocampe à partir d\'IRM 7 Tesla à très haute résolution spatiale</a>  -  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible 	"files/job_offers/stage_classification.pdf" >Automatic classification of patients with Alzheimer\'s disease from Magnetic Resonance Imaging data</a>  - <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Starting date: as soon as possible   Other positions &nbsp;'

 'Clinica <div class="col-md-3"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-667" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/clinica_icon_flat.png" alt="Clinica" width="100%" height="auto" /> <div class="col-md-8">  <span class="softdescription"> Clinica is a software platform for multimodal brain image analysis in clinical research studies. It makes it easy to apply advanced analysis tools to large scale clinical studies. For that purpose
 it integrates a comprehensive set of processing tools for the main neuroimaging modalities: currently MRI (anatomical
 functional
 diffusion) and PET
 in the future
 EEG/MEG. For each modality
 Clinica allows to easily extract various types of features (regional measures
 parametric maps
 surfaces
 curves
 networks). Such features are then subsequently used as input of machine learning
 statistical modeling
 morphometry or network analysis methods.   <u>References</u> <ul>	A. Routier
 N. Burgos
 M. Díaz
 M. Bacci
 S. Bottani
 O. El Rifai
 S. Fontanella
 P. Gori
 J. Guillon
 A. Guyot
 R. Hassanaly
 T. Jacquemont
 P. Lu
 A. Marcoux
 T. Moreau
 J. Samper-González
 M. Teichmann. E. Thibeau-Sutre
 G. Vaillant
 J. Wen
 A. Wild
 M.-O. Habert
 S. Durrleman
 O. Colliot –  Clinica: an open source software platform for reproducible clinical neuroscience studies
 <strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Frontiers in Neuroinformatics</strong></em>
 2021. "https://hal.inria.fr/hal-02549242/document"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /></a> "https://hal.inria.fr/hal-02308126/document"  rel="noopener">Paper in PDFWen J
 Thibeau-Sutre E
 Samper-González J
 Routier A
 Bottani S
 Durrleman S
 Burgos N
 Colliot O:  Convolutional Neural Networks for Classification of Alzheimer’s Disease: Overview and Reproducible Evaluation</em>
 <span style="text-decoration: underline;"> <strong>Medical Image Analysis</strong></em>
 63: 101694
 2020 "https://hal.inria.fr/hal-02562504/document"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /> Paper in PDFRoutier A
 Marcoux A
 Diaz Melo M
 Samper-González J
 Wild A
 Guyot A
 Wen J
 Thibeau- Sutre E
 Bottani S
 Durrleman S
 Burgos N
 Colliot O:  New Longitudinal and Deep Learning Pipelines in the Clinica Software Platform</em>
 <span style="text-decoration: underline;"> <strong>OHBM</strong></em>
 2020. "https://hal.inria.fr/hal-02549242/document"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /> Paper in PDFSamper-González J
 Burgos N
 Bottani S
 Fontanella S
 Lu P
 Marcoux A
 Routier A
 Guillon J
 Bacci M
 Wen J
 Bertrand A
 Bertin H
 Habert MO
 Durrleman S
 Evgeniou T
 Colliot O.  Reproducible evaluation of classification methods in Alzheimer\'s disease: Framework and application to MRI and PET data</em>
 <strong> <u>Neuroimage</u></em></strong> 
 </em>183: 504–521
 2018. "https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01858384/document"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /> Paper in PDFMarcoux A
 Burgos N
 Bertrand A
 Teichmann M
 Routier A
 Wen J
 Samper-González J
 Bottani S
 Durrleman S
 Habert M-O
 Colliot O:  An Automated Pipeline for the Analysis of PET Data on the Cortical Surface</em>
 <strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> Frontiers in Neuroinformatics</em></strong>
 12
 2018. "https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fninf.2018.00094/pdf"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /> Paper in PDF</a>   <div class="col-sm-4">[su_button url="http://www.clinica.run/" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Website[/su_button] <div class="col-sm-4">[su_button url="https://github.com/aramis-lab/clinica" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Code repository[/su_button] <div class="col-sm-4">[su_button url="mailto:olivier.colliot(a)inria(dot)fr" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Contact[/su_button]    ClinicaDL<img class="size-medium wp-image-1886 alignright" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/version_pieuvre_noire-300x289.png" alt="" width="300" height="289" />  <span class="softdescription"> ClinicaDL is an open-source deep learning software for reproducible neuroimaging processing. This library was developed from the "https://github.com/aramis-lab/AD-DL">AD-DL project</a>. The combination of ClinicaDL and Clinica allows performing an end-to-end neuroimaging analysis
 from the download of raw data sets to the interpretation of trained networks
 including neuroimaging preprocessing
 quality check
 label definition
 architecture search
 and network training and evaluation. We implemented ClinicaDL to bring answers to three common issues encountered by deep learning users who are not always familiar with neuroimaging data: (1) the format and preprocessing of neuroimaging data sets
 (2) the contamination of the evaluation procedure by data leakage and (3) a lack of reproducibility.  <u>References</u> <ul>	Elina Thibeau-Sutre
 Mauricio Diaz
 Ravi Hassanaly
 Alexandre Routier
 Didier Dormont
 Olivier Colliot
 Ninon Burgos:  ClinicaDL: an open-source deep learning software for reproducible neuroimaging processing
 <strong>HAL Preprint</strong></em>
 2021. "https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fninf.2018.00094/pdf"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /></a> "https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fninf.2018.00094/pdf"  Paper in PDF</a>   <div class="col-md-8">  <div class="col-sm-4">[su_button url="https://clinicadl.readthedocs.io/en/stable/" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Website[/su_button] <div class="col-sm-4">[su_button url="https://github.com/aramis-lab/clinicaDL" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Code repository[/su_button] <div class="col-sm-4">[su_button url="mailto:ninon.burgos(at)inria(dot)fr" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Contact[/su_button]    Leaspy<img class="size-medium wp-image-1890 alignleft" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/leaspy_logo-300x180.png" alt="" width="300" height="180" />  <div class="col-md-8"> <span class="softdescription"> Leaspy is a software package for the statistical analysis of <strong>longitudinal data</strong>
 particularly <strong>medical</strong> data that comes in a form of <strong>repeated observations</strong> of patients at different time-points. Considering these series of short-term data
 the software aims at :  <ul dir="auto">	recombining them to reconstruct the long-term spatio-temporal trajectory of evolution	positioning each patient observations relatively to the group-average timeline
 in term of both temporal differences (time shift and acceleration factor) and spatial differences (different sequences of events
 spatial pattern of progression
 ...)	quantifying impact of cofactors (gender
 genetic mutation
 environmental factors
 ...) on the evolution of the signal	imputing missing values	predicting future observations	simulating virtual patients to un-bias the initial cohort or mimics its characteristics   <u>References</u> <ul>	I. Koval
 A. Bone
 M. Louis
 S. Bottani
 A. Marcoux
 J. Samper-Gonzalez
 N. Burgos
 B. Charlier
 A. Bertrand
 S. Epelbaum
 O. Colliot
 S. Allassonniere &amp; S. Durrleman
  Intensive application for Alzheimer\'s Disease progression: AD Course Map charts Alzheimer\'s disease progression</em>
  <strong><u>Scientific Reports</u></strong></em><u>,</u> 2021. "http://www.jmlr.org/papers/volume18/17-197/17-197.pdf"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /></a> "https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01964821v3/document">Paper in PDFSchiratti J-B
 Allassonniere S
 Colliot O
 Durrleman S. A Bayesian mixed-efects model to learn trajectories of changes from repeated manifold-valued observations</em>. In <strong> <u>Journal of Machine Learning Research (JMLR)</u></em></strong> 18(1)
 4840-4872. 2017. "http://www.jmlr.org/papers/volume18/17-197/17-197.pdf"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /> Paper in PDFKoval I
 Schiratti JB
 Routier A
 Bacci M
 Colliot M
 Allassonnière S
 Durrleman S.  Spatiotemporal propagation of the cortical atrophy: population and individual patterns</em>. In <strong> <u>Frontiers in Neurology</u></em></strong> 9
 2018. "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5945895/"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /> Paper in PDF</a>;  <div class="col-sm-4">[su_button url="https://disease-progression-modelling.github.io/pages/models/disease_course_mapping.html" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Website[/su_button] <div class="col-sm-4">[su_button url="https://gitlab.com/icm-institute/aramislab/leaspy" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Code repository[/su_button] <div class="col-sm-4">[su_button url="mailto:stanley.durrleman(at)inria(dot)fr" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Contact[/su_button]    Deformetrica<img class="size-medium wp-image-1886 alignright" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/deformetrica.png" alt="Clinica" width="196" height="145" />  <div class="col-md-8"><span class="softdescription"> Deformetrica is a software for the statistical analysis of 2D and 3D shape data. It essentially computes deformations of the 2D or 3D ambient space
 which
 in turn
 warp any object embedded in this space
 whether this object is a curve
 a surface
 a structured or unstructured set of points
 or any combination of them. <div class="col-md-8"><span class="softdescription">  <u>References</u> <ul>	S. Durrleman
 S.
 Prastawa
 M.
 Charon
 N.
 Korenberg
 J.R.
 Joshi

 Gerig
 G.

 2014 "http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1053811914005205"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /> Paper in PDFBône
 A.
 Louis
 M.
 Martin
 B.
 &amp; Durrleman
 S.   Deformetrica 4: an open-source software for statistical shape analysis.</em> In <strong> <u>nternational Workshop on Shape in Medical Imaging</u></em></strong> Springer
 Cham
 2018. p. 3-13. "https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01874752/document"  <img src="../files/images/pdf-logo_crop2.jpg" alt="PDF" width="20" height="20" align="absmiddle" border="0" /> Paper in PDF</a>;  <div class="col-md-6">[su_button url="http://www.deformetrica.org/" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Website[/su_button] <div class="col-md-6">[su_button url="mailto:stanley.durrleman(a)inria(dot)fr" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Contact[/su_button]    Brain network toolbox <div class="col-md-3"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-691" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Logo_alto_100.png" alt="Logo_alto_100" width="100%" height="auto" /> <div class="col-md-8"><span class="softdescription"> A list of MATLAB routines for characterizing brain network topology though graph theoretical indices can be found at the website of the FreeBorN consortium
 which promotes the interaction and visibility of the research teams studying brain connectivity and network theory.  <div class="col-md-6">[su_button url="https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Website[/su_button] <div class="col-md-6">[su_button url="mailto:fabrizio.devicofallani(a)gmail(dot)com" size="5" style="flat" background="#702082" color="white" center="yes"]Contact[/su_button]    &nbsp;'

 '2014-09-30 13:30:03'
 '2014-09-30 12:30:03'
 '<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Deformetrica</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"http://www.deformetrica.org/" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-638" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Deformetrica_logo_alto-e1410446726535.png" alt="Deformetrica_logo_alto" width="196" height="100" />Deformetrica</a> is a software for the statistical analysis of 2D and 3D shape data. It essentially computes deformations of the 2D or 3D ambient space
 which
 in turn
 warp any object embedded in this space
 whether this object is a curve
 a surface
 a structured or unstructured set of points
 or any combination of them.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: stanley.durrleman@inria.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1053811914005205" >S. Durrleman et al. Morphometry of anatomical shape complexes with dense deformations and sparse parameters. <strong>NeuroImage. </strong>101(1): 35-49
 2014.</a>; <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Sacha</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-661" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Sacha_310_height.png" alt="logo_sacha_v1_trans" width="196" height="100" />SACHA (Segmentation Automatisée Compétitive de l’Hippocampe et de l’Amygdale) is a software dedicated to the joint segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala from 3D-T1 MRI brain scans ([1]
 [2]) with prior knowledge on the location of the hippocampus and the amygdala derived from a probabilistic atlas and relative positions with respect to automatically identified anatomical landmarks. This method has been validated by comparison with manual tracing in healthy controls
 patients with Alzheimer’s disease and patients with epilepsy ([1]
 [2]). It has also been successfully applied to over 5,000 MRI scans in patients with various conditions ([3]
 [4]
 [5]
 [6]).</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">References: <ol> "https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/marie_neuroimage2009.pdf" >Chupin M et al. Automatic segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala driven by hybrid constraints: method and validation. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 46:749-761
 2009</a>. Chupin M et al. Anatomically constrained region deformation for the automated segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala: Method and validation on controls and patients with Alzheimer\'s disease. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 34:996-1019
 2007. Chupin M et al. Fully automatic hippocampus segmentation and classification in Alzheimer\'s disease and mild cognitive impairment applied on data from ADNI. <strong>Hippocampus</strong> 19:579-587
 2009. Colliot O et al. Discrimination between Alzheimer disease
 mild cognitive impairment
 and normal aging by using automated segmentation of the hippocampus. <strong>Radiology</strong> 248:194-201
 2008. </ol> &nbsp; <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Whasa</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-667" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Whasa_196_145.png" alt="WHASA" width="196" height="145" />WHASA (White matter Hyperintensities Automated Segmentation Algorithm) is an algorithm for the automated segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities (WMH). This approach segments hyperintensities from T2-FLAIR and 3D T1 MRI brain scans. The method has been validated by comparison with manual tracings in 67 patients acquired on 6 different 1.5T MRI scanners with various sequences as used in clinical routine (slice thickness on FLAIR images about 5mm). It has also been applied to over 1000 patients from various centres with both 1.5 and 3T MRI scanners.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr and ludovic.fillon@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/thomas_PLoS_One_published.pdf" >T. Samaille
 L. Fillon et al. Contrast-Based Fully Automatic Segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities: Method and Validation. <strong>PLoS ONE. </strong>7(11): e48953
 2012.</a>; <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Brain network toolbox</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-691" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Logo_alto_100.png" alt="Logo_alto_100" width="196" height="100" /></a> A list of MATLAB routines for characterizing brain network topology though graph theoretical indices can be found at the website of the FreeBorN consortium
 which promotes the interaction and visibility of the research teams studying brain connectivity and network theory.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: fabrizio.devicofallani@gmail.com and mario.chavez@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" >https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download</a>'
 'Software'

 '<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Deformetrica</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"http://www.deformetrica.org/" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-638" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Deformetrica_logo_alto-e1410446726535.png" alt="Deformetrica_logo_alto" width="196" height="100" />Deformetrica</a> is a software for the statistical analysis of 2D and 3D shape data. It essentially computes deformations of the 2D or 3D ambient space
 which
 in turn
 warp any object embedded in this space
 whether this object is a curve
 a surface
 a structured or unstructured set of points
 or any combination of them.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: stanley.durrleman@inria.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1053811914005205" >S. Durrleman et al. Morphometry of anatomical shape complexes with dense deformations and sparse parameters. <strong>NeuroImage. </strong>101(1): 35-49
 2014.</a>; <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Sacha</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-661" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Sacha_310_height.png" alt="logo_sacha_v1_trans" width="196" height="100" />SACHA (Segmentation Automatisée Compétitive de l’Hippocampe et de l’Amygdale) is a software dedicated to the joint segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala from 3D-T1 MRI brain scans ([1]
 [2]) with prior knowledge on the location of the hippocampus and the amygdala derived from a probabilistic atlas and relative positions with respect to automatically identified anatomical landmarks. This method has been validated by comparison with manual tracing in healthy controls
 patients with Alzheimer’s disease and patients with epilepsy ([1]
 [2]). It has also been successfully applied to over 5,000 MRI scans in patients with various conditions ([3]
 [4]
 [5]
 [6]).</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">References: <ol> 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/marie_neuroimage2009.pdf" >Chupin M et al. Automatic segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala driven by hybrid constraints: method and validation. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 46:749-761
 2009</a>. 	Chupin M et al. Anatomically constrained region deformation for the automated segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala: Method and validation on controls and patients with Alzheimer\'s disease. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 34:996-1019
 2007. 	Chupin M et al. Fully automatic hippocampus segmentation and classification in Alzheimer\'s disease and mild cognitive impairment applied on data from ADNI. <strong>Hippocampus</strong> 19:579-587
 2009. 	Colliot O et al. Discrimination between Alzheimer disease
 mild cognitive impairment
 and normal aging by using automated segmentation of the hippocampus. <strong>Radiology</strong> 248:194-201
 2008. </ol> &nbsp; <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Whasa</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-667" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Whasa_196_145.png" alt="WHASA" width="196" height="145" />WHASA (White matter Hyperintensities Automated Segmentation Algorithm) is an algorithm for the automated segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities (WMH). This approach segments hyperintensities from T2-FLAIR and 3D T1 MRI brain scans. The method has been validated by comparison with manual tracings in 67 patients acquired on 6 different 1.5T MRI scanners with various sequences as used in clinical routine (slice thickness on FLAIR images about 5mm). It has also been applied to over 1000 patients from various centres with both 1.5 and 3T MRI scanners.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr and ludovic.fillon@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/thomas_PLoS_One_published.pdf" >T. Samaille
 L. Fillon et al. Contrast-Based Fully Automatic Segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities: Method and Validation. <strong>PLoS ONE. </strong>7(11): e48953
 2012.</a>; <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Brain network toolbox</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-691" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Logo_alto_100.png" alt="Logo_alto_100" width="196" height="100" /></a> A list of MATLAB routines for characterizing brain network topology though graph theoretical indices can be found at the website of the FreeBorN consortium
 which promotes the interaction and visibility of the research teams studying brain connectivity and network theory.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: fabrizio.devicofallani@gmail.com and mario.chavez@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" >https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download</a>'

 '<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Sacha</strong></h2>\n<p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-661" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Sacha_310_height.png" alt="logo_sacha_v1_trans" width="196" height="100" />SACHA (Segmentation Automatisée Compétitive de l’Hippocampe et de l’Amygdale) is a software dedicated to the joint segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala from 3D-T1 MRI brain scans ([1]
 [2]) with prior knowledge on the location of the hippocampus and the amygdala derived from a probabilistic atlas and relative positions with respect to automatically identified anatomical landmarks. This method has been validated by comparison with manual tracing in healthy controls
 patients with Alzheimer’s disease and patients with epilepsy ([1]
 [2]). It has also been successfully applied to over 5,000 MRI scans in patients with various conditions ([3]
 [4]
 [5]
 [6]).</p>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr\n\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">References:\n<ol>\n	"https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/marie_neuroimage2009.pdf" >Chupin M et al. Automatic segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala driven by hybrid constraints: method and validation. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 46:749-761
 2009</a>.\n	Chupin M et al. Anatomically constrained region deformation for the automated segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala: Method and validation on controls and patients with Alzheimer\'s disease. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 34:996-1019
 2007.\n	Chupin M et al. Fully automatic hippocampus segmentation and classification in Alzheimer\'s disease and mild cognitive impairment applied on data from ADNI. <strong>Hippocampus</strong> 19:579-587
 2009.\n	Colliot O et al. Discrimination between Alzheimer disease
 mild cognitive impairment
 and normal aging by using automated segmentation of the hippocampus. <strong>Radiology</strong> 248:194-201
 2008.\n</ol>\n&nbsp;\n<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Whasa</strong></h2>\n<p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-667" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Whasa_196_145.png" alt="WHASA" width="196" height="145" />WHASA (White matter Hyperintensities Automated Segmentation Algorithm) is an algorithm for the automated segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities (WMH). This approach segments hyperintensities from T2-FLAIR and 3D T1 MRI brain scans. The method has been validated by comparison with manual tracings in 67 patients acquired on 6 different 1.5T MRI scanners with various sequences as used in clinical routine (slice thickness on FLAIR images about 5mm). It has also been applied to over 1000 patients from various centres with both 1.5 and 3T MRI scanners.</p>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr and ludovic.fillon@upmc.fr\n\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/thomas_PLoS_One_published.pdf" >T. Samaille
 L. Fillon et al. Contrast-Based Fully Automatic Segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities: Method and Validation. <strong>PLoS ONE. </strong>7(11): e48953
 2012.</a>\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Brain network toolbox</strong></h2>\n<p style="text-align: justify;">"https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-691" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Logo_alto_100.png" alt="Logo_alto_100" width="196" height="100" /></a> A list of MATLAB routines for characterizing brain network topology though graph theoretical indices can be found at the website of the FreeBorN consortium
 which promotes the interaction and visibility of the research teams studying brain connectivity and network theory.</p>\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: fabrizio.devicofallani@gmail.com and mario.chavez@upmc.fr\n\n<span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" >https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download</a>\n\n&nbsp;\n\n<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Deformetrica</strong></h2>\n<p style="text-align: justify;">"http://www.deformetrica.org/" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-638" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Deformetrica_logo_usato.png" alt="Deformetrica_logo_alto" width="196" height="100" />Deformetrica</a> is a software for the statistical analysis of 2D and 3D shape data. It essentially computes deformations of the 2D or 3D ambient space
 which
 in turn
 warp any object embedded in this space
 whether this object is a curve

 '<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Sacha</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-661" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Sacha_310_height.png" alt="logo_sacha_v1_trans" width="196" height="100" />SACHA (Segmentation Automatisée Compétitive de l’Hippocampe et de l’Amygdale) is a software dedicated to the joint segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala from 3D-T1 MRI brain scans ([1]
 [2]) with prior knowledge on the location of the hippocampus and the amygdala derived from a probabilistic atlas and relative positions with respect to automatically identified anatomical landmarks. This method has been validated by comparison with manual tracing in healthy controls
 patients with Alzheimer’s disease and patients with epilepsy ([1]
 [2]). It has also been successfully applied to over 5,000 MRI scans in patients with various conditions ([3]
 [4]
 [5]
 [6]).</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">References: <ol> 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/marie_neuroimage2009.pdf" >Chupin M et al. Automatic segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala driven by hybrid constraints: method and validation. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 46:749-761
 2009</a>. 	Chupin M et al. Anatomically constrained region deformation for the automated segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala: Method and validation on controls and patients with Alzheimer\'s disease. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 34:996-1019
 2007. 	Chupin M et al. Fully automatic hippocampus segmentation and classification in Alzheimer\'s disease and mild cognitive impairment applied on data from ADNI. <strong>Hippocampus</strong> 19:579-587
 2009. 	Colliot O et al. Discrimination between Alzheimer disease
 mild cognitive impairment
 and normal aging by using automated segmentation of the hippocampus. <strong>Radiology</strong> 248:194-201
 2008. </ol> &nbsp; <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Whasa</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-667" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Whasa_196_145.png" alt="WHASA" width="196" height="145" />WHASA (White matter Hyperintensities Automated Segmentation Algorithm) is an algorithm for the automated segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities (WMH). This approach segments hyperintensities from T2-FLAIR and 3D T1 MRI brain scans. The method has been validated by comparison with manual tracings in 67 patients acquired on 6 different 1.5T MRI scanners with various sequences as used in clinical routine (slice thickness on FLAIR images about 5mm). It has also been applied to over 1000 patients from various centres with both 1.5 and 3T MRI scanners.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr and ludovic.fillon@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/thomas_PLoS_One_published.pdf" >T. Samaille
 L. Fillon et al. Contrast-Based Fully Automatic Segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities: Method and Validation. <strong>PLoS ONE. </strong>7(11): e48953
 2012.</a>;  <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Deformetrica</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"http://www.deformetrica.org/" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-638" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Deformetrica_logo_alto-e1410446726535.png" alt="Deformetrica_logo_alto" width="196" height="100" />Deformetrica</a> is a software for the statistical analysis of 2D and 3D shape data. It essentially computes deformations of the 2D or 3D ambient space
 which
 in turn
 warp any object embedded in this space
 whether this object is a curve
 a surface
 a structured or unstructured set of points
 or any combination of them.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: stanley.durrleman@inria.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1053811914005205" >S. Durrleman et al. Morphometry of anatomical shape complexes with dense deformations and sparse parameters. <strong>NeuroImage. </strong>101(1): 35-49
 2014.</a>; <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Brain network toolbox</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-691" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Logo_alto_100.png" alt="Logo_alto_100" width="196" height="100" /></a> A list of MATLAB routines for characterizing brain network topology though graph theoretical indices can be found at the website of the FreeBorN consortium

 '<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Sacha</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-661" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Sacha_310_height.png" alt="logo_sacha_v1_trans" width="196" height="100" />SACHA (Segmentation Automatisée Compétitive de l’Hippocampe et de l’Amygdale) is a software dedicated to the joint segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala from 3D-T1 MRI brain scans ([1]
 [2]) with prior knowledge on the location of the hippocampus and the amygdala derived from a probabilistic atlas and relative positions with respect to automatically identified anatomical landmarks. This method has been validated by comparison with manual tracing in healthy controls

 [2]). It has also been successfully applied to over 5,000 MRI scans in patients with various conditions ([3]

 mild cognitive impairment

 '<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Sacha</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-661" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Sacha_310_height.png" alt="logo_sacha_v1_trans" width="196" height="100" />SACHA (Segmentation Automatisée Compétitive de l’Hippocampe et de l’Amygdale) is a software dedicated to the joint segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala from 3D-T1 MRI brain scans ([1]
 [2]) with prior knowledge on the location of the hippocampus and the amygdala derived from a probabilistic atlas and relative positions with respect to automatically identified anatomical landmarks. This method has been validated by comparison with manual tracing in healthy controls
 patients with Alzheimer’s disease and patients with epilepsy ([1]
 [2]). It has also been successfully applied to over 5,000 MRI scans in patients with various conditions ([3]
 [4]
 [5]
 [6]).</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">References: <ol> 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/marie_neuroimage2009.pdf" >Chupin M et al. Automatic segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala driven by hybrid constraints: method and validation. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 46:749-761
 2009</a>. 	Chupin M et al. Anatomically constrained region deformation for the automated segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala: Method and validation on controls and patients with Alzheimer\'s disease. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 34:996-1019
 2007. 	Chupin M et al. Fully automatic hippocampus segmentation and classification in Alzheimer\'s disease and mild cognitive impairment applied on data from ADNI. <strong>Hippocampus</strong> 19:579-587
 2009. 	Colliot O et al. Discrimination between Alzheimer disease
 mild cognitive impairment
 and normal aging by using automated segmentation of the hippocampus. <strong>Radiology</strong> 248:194-201
 2008. </ol> &nbsp; <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Whasa</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-667" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Whasa_196_145.png" alt="WHASA" width="196" height="145" />WHASA (White matter Hyperintensities Automated Segmentation Algorithm) is an algorithm for the automated segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities (WMH). This approach segments hyperintensities from T2-FLAIR and 3D T1 MRI brain scans. The method has been validated by comparison with manual tracings in 67 patients acquired on 6 different 1.5T MRI scanners with various sequences as used in clinical routine (slice thickness on FLAIR images about 5mm). It has also been applied to over 1000 patients from various centres with both 1.5 and 3T MRI scanners.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr and ludovic.fillon@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/thomas_PLoS_One_published.pdf" >T. Samaille
 L. Fillon et al. Contrast-Based Fully Automatic Segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities: Method and Validation. <strong>PLoS ONE. </strong>7(11): e48953
 2012.</a>;  <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Brain network toolbox</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-691" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Logo_alto_100.png" alt="Logo_alto_100" width="196" height="100" /></a> A list of MATLAB routines for characterizing brain network topology though graph theoretical indices can be found at the website of the FreeBorN consortium
 which promotes the interaction and visibility of the research teams studying brain connectivity and network theory.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: fabrizio.devicofallani@gmail.com and mario.chavez@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" >https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download</a>;  <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Deformetrica</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"http://www.deformetrica.org/" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-638" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Deformetrica_logo_usato.png" alt="Deformetrica_logo_alto" width="196" height="100" />Deformetrica</a> is a software for the statistical analysis of 2D and 3D shape data. It essentially computes deformations of the 2D or 3D ambient space
 which
 in turn
 warp any object embedded in this space
 whether this object is a curve
 a surface
 a structured or unstructured set of points
 or any combination of them.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: stanley.durrleman@inria.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1053811914005205" >S. Durrleman et al. Morphometry of anatomical shape complexes with dense deformations and sparse parameters. <strong>NeuroImage. </strong>101(1): 35-49
 2014.</a>'

 '<h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Sacha</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-661" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Sacha_310_height.png" alt="logo_sacha_v1_trans" width="196" height="100" />SACHA (Segmentation Automatisée Compétitive de l’Hippocampe et de l’Amygdale) is a software dedicated to the joint segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala from 3D-T1 MRI brain scans ([1]
 [2]) with prior knowledge on the location of the hippocampus and the amygdala derived from a probabilistic atlas and relative positions with respect to automatically identified anatomical landmarks. This method has been validated by comparison with manual tracing in healthy controls
 patients with Alzheimer’s disease and patients with epilepsy ([1]
 [2]). It has also been successfully applied to over 5,000 MRI scans in patients with various conditions ([3]
 [4]
 [5]
 [6]).</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">References: <ol> 	"https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/marie_neuroimage2009.pdf" >Chupin M et al.  2009</a>. 	Chupin M et al. Anatomically constrained region deformation for the automated segmentation of the hippocampus and the amygdala: Method and validation on controls and patients with Alzheimer\'s disease. <strong>Neuroimage</strong> 34:996-1019
 2007. 	Chupin M et al. Fully automatic hippocampus segmentation and classification in Alzheimer\'s disease and mild cognitive impairment applied on data from ADNI. <strong>Hippocampus</strong> 19:579-587
 2009. 	Colliot O et al. Discrimination between Alzheimer disease
 mild cognitive impairment
 and normal aging by using automated segmentation of the hippocampus. <strong>Radiology</strong> 248:194-201
 2008. </ol> &nbsp; <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Whasa</strong><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-667" src="http://aramislab.preprod.lamp.cnrs.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Whasa_196_145.png" alt="WHASA" width="196" height="145" />WHASA (White matter Hyperintensities Automated Segmentation Algorithm) is an algorithm for the automated segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities (WMH). This approach segments hyperintensities from T2-FLAIR and 3D T1 MRI brain scans. The method has been validated by comparison with manual tracings in 67 patients acquired on 6 different 1.5T MRI scanners with various sequences as used in clinical routine (slice thickness on FLAIR images about 5mm). It has also been applied to over 1000 patients from various centres with both 1.5 and 3T MRI scanners.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: marie.chupin@upmc.fr and ludovic.fillon@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://www.aramislab.fr/perso/colliot/files/thomas_PLoS_One_published.pdf" >T. Samaille
 L. Fillon et al. Contrast-Based Fully Automatic Segmentation of White Matter Hyperintensities: Method and Validation. <strong>PLoS ONE. </strong>7(11): e48953
 2012.</a>;  <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Brain network toolbox</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-691" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Logo_alto_100.png" alt="Logo_alto_100" width="196" height="100" /></a> A list of MATLAB routines for characterizing brain network topology though graph theoretical indices can be found at the website of the FreeBorN consortium
 which promotes the interaction and visibility of the research teams studying brain connectivity and network theory.</p> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Contacts: fabrizio.devicofallani@gmail.com and mario.chavez@upmc.fr  <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Reference: "https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download" >https://sites.google.com/site/fr2eborn/download</a>;  <h2 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Deformetrica</strong><p style="text-align: justify;">"http://www.deformetrica.org/" ><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-638" src="https://www.aramislab.fr/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Deformetrica_logo_usato.png" alt="Deformetrica_logo_alto" width="196" height="100" />Deformetrica</a> is a software for the statistical analysis of 2D and 3D shape data. It essentially computes deformations of the 2D or 3D ambient space
 which
 in turn
 warp any object embedded in this space
 whether this object is a curve
